movie_review_blurb: Toni Erdmann is seriously funny, yes, but there are also very real emotional stakes behind every joke.
The result is a disjointed and inconsequential film whose chakras are in urgent need of realignment.
The film loses the palpable tension it manages to set up in the beginning
Blanchett, wielding a stiff cocktail in one hand and a bottle of anti-anxiety pills in the other, gives her character a skillful shove from neurotic towards psychotic.
The result is a quiet power-so quiet in fact that the score is almost non-existent-that never risks sentimentality or exploitation.
Scott McGehee and David Siegel's adaptation commendably preserves the book's child perspective even if it doesn't quite match the characteristically dark shades of the author's moral fare.
The muddled mental states of the characters (and that of the audience) are mirrored by the film's visual style, which oscillates between languorous dreamscapes and frenetic action sequences.
The bleak backdrop is rendered with great beauty-so much so that perhaps the sensory poetics of the visuals linger beyond their darker implications.
But Silver Linings Playbook never induces a roll of the eyes, even if it never really surprises.
Scorn may give way to momentary solicitude, but Sister is by no means a tenderhearted morality tale.

Forcing his characters into moral gray zones, the director weakens the notion of objectivity, allowing the viewer's allegiances to shift freely among the household's denizens-even if as individuals, none of them is particularly sympathetic.
The physicality of the overgrown Swifty and exceptionally runty Arbor make them a particularly endearing odd couple to watch, and their friendship feels real, from start to tragic finish.
Like any adaptation, the film glosses over some of the finer details of the novel, but it preserves the author's moral ambiguity towards his characters.
Beneath the onslaught of contemporary in-jokes and one bad fedora, Baumbach manages to articulate, with a great deal of poignancy, the timeless challenge of aging
Streaked with the director's decidedly modern strain of cynicism, Love & Friendship might very well be the most faithful translation of Austen's biting humor and highly practical feminism to date.
Kechiche's visual style combined with the actresses' truly astounding performances make this film impossible to view from a safe distance.
Cynics may scoff at the fact that Infinitely Polar Bear glosses some of the filmmaker's darker memories, but they'll need an ice bucket handy if they intend to avoid its warmth altogether.
Teasing the audience with prolonged suspense is one of Refn's specialties, and at its best, the sensation manifests itself viscerally.
Revealing both the dangers and payoffs of artistic ambition, Whiplash is sure to establish Chazelle as a directorial force to be reckoned with.
Genuinely moving but never maudlin, Remote Area Medical lays bare the injustice of a system that fails to provide for those who need it most.
Even if the film doesn't leave much to ponder past the closing credits, it's enjoyable while it's unfolding, doing justice to the strengths of Shelton's ever-expanding filmography.

Frank in its depiction of eroticism and emotion alike, Frias' ability to articulate the ephemeral aspects of human connection elevates his film to something greater than the sum of its itinerant parts, establishing him as a talent to watch.
Olnek is clearly a talented writer, and it's unfortunate for a film with such a promising premise that the one-liners and situational humor don't add up to more than the sum of their parts.
Like its central character, Listen Up Philip exudes a kind of highbrow affectation that charms more than it alienates.
the fine art of erotic manipulation is gleefully on display
At once a perverse psycho-sexual thriller and a venomous comedy of manners, Elle boldly wears its contractions on its sleeve.
Vitkova renders this highly personal story with great pathos that showcases her truly inventive sense of humor.
Frozen River is a taut, suspenseful thriller; a troubling of borders both cultural and national; and testament to the virtues of communion, empathy and compassion.
A film that's ambiguous, involving and very intelligent indeed.
Cleverly employing the florid self-consciousness of the theatre world into which it offers us a glimpse, Me and Orson Welles elicits an irresistible grin.
More fair-weather friend than fine friend.
So shockingly bad, it is really, extraordinarily good.
The quiet understatement of the work bears endless reflection.
Employing a suitably chiaroscuro film language to balance the emotional extremes of the subject matter, his vision is a lively composite of urban nightmare and garish escapism.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It seems more like an hour-and-a-half-long infomercial for America than a narrative film or documentary. Like something you might hallucinate on Flag Day.
Sometimes a film has you swooning from the very first frame, and Polish director Pawel Pawlikowski's fifth narrative feature is one such film.
How wonderful that a film that is so unapologetically frank should simultaneously feel so warm and delightful.
A comedy classic that boasts some of Groucho's prickliest zingers and the pinnacle of Harpo's mirthful mischief.
Heartbreak porn and little more.
An elegantly presented story of a seemingly honourable businessman beset on all sides by corruption and criminality.
Garland has produced something seductively strange, consistently thought-provoking and admirably adult.
Swaggering and dialogue-heavy, The Gambler certainly talks the talk, but ultimately it lacks the courage of its convictions.
Like the Thomas Pynchon novel on which it's based, Inherent Vice is an anti-thriller, a loose, lunatic, sun-scorched noir that just keeps piling on the madness.
Notable for its insight and refreshing lack of sentimentality.
Superficial pleasures aside, this sun-bleached buddy crime flick is too light for the long game.
By presenting its ideas in a well-structured, appealingly fleshed-out fashion it lives up to its name in more ways than one.
It's a charming, appealingly orchestrated illustration of a simple message: times may change but love is eternal.
movie_title: Love Is All: 100 Years of Love & Courtship (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Given the constraints and need to please its considerable fan-base, this sleek, fairly trim and occasionally sensual adaptation is the best imaginable outcome.
Hazanavicius boldly strips cinema back to its wordless, monochrome days and, boy, does the end result sparkle.
Perceptive, funny and cringingly honest ...
Blind is a fascinating journey into the mind and body of an outsider, with generous helpings of cinematic audacity, mischief and trickery.

The film is hobbled by a naff, TV-movie aesthetic and jarringly mawkish score. Yet Moore gives us raw heartache, running the gauntlet from fear to fury to powerless frustration, before she's barely there at all.
Explores uneven relationships and rivalries in a manner seldom seen onscreen.
Blackhat is an inconsistent, ill-conceived affair which rarely, if ever, rings true.
James Marsh's film reorders events and soft-soaps the acrimony, yet boasts an appealingly unconventional coupling and eye-catching performances from its shooting star leads.
Thou Wast Mild and Lovely is as horrible as it is beautiful and that's just grand.

The sweetly appealing Coltrane shoots up before our eyes and doesn't buckle under the scrutiny, but if Mason is our ostensible focus then his mother Olivia (Patricia Arquette) is the movie's unsung heroine.

The film's prurient philosophising can be frustratingly pithy but there's a cheeky gag around every corner and the imaginative visuals, committed performances and tendency to transgress mean things are never less than interesting.
movie_title: You and the Night (Les rencontres d'après minuit) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An endearingly dog-eared, scrappy film that puts up its dukes for outsiders and is at its best when showcasing its leftfield, lower-key charms.
Another middling effort from a former movie maestro.
It might at first seem like a comedy but, with its mounting horrors and nod to those currently in charge, sadly it's clear that the joke is on us.
This fiercely beautiful amalgam will sweep you up in its masterful, thrillingly macabre embrace before sending you swooning out of the cinema. It's like waltzing with Count Dracula.
A fair amount of unintentional amusement aside, there's little here to enjoy.
An elegant, effective thriller which shows the impact we have on the lives of others; how, with so much else in play, our futures may not be ours to decide.

The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel squeaks through on its positivity and humour, with its sharp wit and trite wisdom delivered by a cast who could give a party political broadcast integrity and emotional impact.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Duke of Burgundy tears down the facade of a sadomasochist relationship, exposing the vulnerability and crippling anxiety behind the leather and lasciviousness, while tempering its turmoil with a surprising amount of wit.
An exemplary example of how to combine multiple stories in a coherent, complementary and often exhilarating manner.
Never short of enthralling.
The conviction of the leads saves this from being a total stinker, although an ending of industrial strength stupidity places it a mere whisker away.
Amirpour and her team effectively employ chiaroscuro and create an old-fashioned, almost unearthed aesthetic.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to take your eyes off Carell, compellingly creepy as someone who's grown up under a withering gaze, and whose effortful self-containment is undermined by that dangerous flicker in his eyes.
Whiplash is everything its snappy title suggests, and comes complete with a thunderous ending that leaves the entire film reverberating in your consciousness.
That it wastes the talent of two young actors with star potential is upsetting, that it insults its audience is frankly unforgivable.

Dolan's previous four films established him as an original and exciting voice. With the wildly funny, emotionally messy and wholly wonderful Mommy the filmmaker steps into the big league - aged just 25.
There are enough flashes of the film it might have been to make it worth watching.
It's a funny, fitting, warts-and-all monument to a British master, with Mike Leigh demonstrating a command of his craft to rival even his subject.
Debut director Dan Gilroy has crafted a characterful satire that doesn't say much that's original but which skewers its targets with humour and flair.
The script comprises stiff scientific discussion, clunky exposition and cinematic clichés and, frankly, it all gets a bit silly.

This transitional effort's teething problems aside, it's crammed with well-drawn characters and intelligent ideas, meaning the franchise remains as robust and rule-breaking as its idiosyncratic protagonist.
This tough and tender biopic ... makes for an elegant, occasionally exciting tribute to a man and his art-form.
What Burton's approach most lacks is insight - big eyes don't see too deeply - but it's still a fascinating story told with flair.

A ponderously paced but artistically sure journey; it's a film that finds strength in the universality of its ideas and its spiritual dimension, one that's enlivened by instantly iconic imagery and a keen sense of the strange.
There's nuance in the performances and bite in the script, but it could have done with a stronger hand behind the camera to blend it all together.
Intoxicating, ferocious, and righteously disturbing but also frustrating, uneven and clichéd.
The ponderous pace and initial lack of focus will prove testing to some but this is a slow, steady film that builds in power almost imperceptibly, working its way deep under your skin.
The unusual premise turns out to be a fruitful way to explore the shadow of exes, and the danger of simply loving someone, in a film that's insightful, haunting and desperately sad.

We've seen zombie films of all shades - from satires to splatterfests to rom-zom-coms - but rarely one which lingers so mournfully on the haemorrhaging of humanity, and which prizes it highly enough to do so.
Painfully funny and brilliantly performed.

An admirable but flawed film that's visually ambitious and that confronts difficult issues like isolation, romantic delusion and the terrible legacy of unchecked anger, not wholly successfully but with intermittent charm and no shortage of pathos.
Famuyiwa's fifth film sets itself apart from gritty urban dramas with its non-conformist leads, bounce and cheerful aesthetic that skilfully fuses the retro and contemporary.
Magic Mike XXL is as sweet and steamy as oven-fresh cherry pie.
Rich with casually relayed social observation and parody, presenting its odd behaviour, incompetent police-work and murderous, hate-fuelled chaos without fanfare.
Simien helms with style to spare but makes sure the emphasis is firmly on substance, as he offers great insight into the contradictions and concerns of young black culture.

Most of all, it's a film that knows the value of its appealing young stars and that makes their credible and entertaining antics its focus, winning you over with the squeals and strops of these tiny worker bees.
The Dark Knight Rises succeeds because it's rooted in real-world experiences and fears.
Alberto Rodríguez's sixth film is a police procedural with real gravitas that pleasures in the contrast and competence of its grizzled leads.
As ever with Baumbach, this is rich and intellectually ambitious but it flounders as it descends into farce - just like Brooke, it's not quite sure where it wants to go.
The laughs are hearty and abundant and Schumer's schtick is so distinct and refreshing that it's miles from the disaster the title suggests.

The Dance of Reality is a surprisingly moving, emotionally satisfying experience, which twirls you round in a warm, confident embrace, making sure to toss in plenty of its director's signature madcap moves.
How wonderful that, especially in its newly finessed form, this cinematic milestone remains as pertinent, intriguing and seductive as ever.

As insultingly cursory as the original, the film suffers from a fractured, sense-shorn narrative that makes huge leaps in logic and almost no attempt to address the complexities and controversies of its genetics storyline.
Lovingly assembled, fist-pumping fun - a treat for big kids who like their triumph-over-adversity drenched in buckets of blood.
The terrifically effective premise allows for great humour and pin-sharp yet light-touch social commentary, and Val is a character to cherish.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Oram's first-feature proves consistently intriguing and reliably amusing. The performers are beyond game, with the cream-of-the-British-comedy-crop cast investing proceedings with energy, conviction and variety.
An entertaining showcase for its versatile leading man, this oddly but defiantly upbeat film seldom fails to fascinate, even when it's for the wrong reasons.
It's undeniably on the slight side but this is an endearingly scrappy film with a fighter's spunk and a lover's heart that doesn't surrender to sentimentality.
A penetrating study of human weakness, Force Majeure shows us things about these characters, and by extension ourselves, that we might not want to see.
Jurassic World has enough scares, scale, ideas and variety to keep every generation on the edge of their seats. It's good ol' family entertainment - just with much bigger teeth.

Sherlock Jr. is notable for a series of scintillating, near-inexplicable stunts, Keaton's characteristically dexterous and deadpan performance, as well as for its fat-free rattling-good storytelling and witty intertitles.
The female-fronted confessional comedy is given a Middle Eastern twist in writer/director Desiree Akhavan's sharply penned feature debut, in which she also stars.
A perfect example of a film that captures the spirit of the source-material, whilst boldly exploiting and exploring the potential of the cinematic medium.
It's a film that knows and loves science-fiction cinema: its grimy dystopian milieu and social conscience marries it, perhaps too closely, to the director's previous films.
Whatever its flaws, this melodrama is genuinely affecting, with a message that's undeniably on point.
This film isn't taking itself too seriously, and it certainly doesn't expect us to.
Sadly, it's only the ludicrous moments that really stay with you.
Ultimately it's a film that didn't need this many bells and whistles for it to pack an almighty punch.
Modern life may indeed be rubbish but Andersson communicates that sentiment with a certain amount of sorrow and an awful lot of style.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A lovingly crafted, pleasingly characterful effort that delivers impactful, imaginatively executed thrills.
It's a little too wedded to the cinematic past.

It's hard not to admire how efficiently and enjoyably the myriad elements have been threaded together; Age of Ultron is a suitably well-oiled machine with an insatiable appetite for family friendly destruction.
Fear of female sexuality is at the heart of this deliciously dreamy drama from writer/director Carol Morley.
The story remains gripping and the cast is wonderful, with Mulligan proving an altogether less tortured Hardy heroine than usual.
If it fails to consistently transcend its narrative troubles Phoenix does, on occasion, take flight.
This is a little film with a lot of power.
The casting is spot on, with head honcho Pal Sverre Hagen's preening appearance and exuberant villainy making an effective counterpoint to Skarsgård's stone-faced everyman.

Movies on this scale have often been the worst offenders when it comes to failing to put women and the issues they face at the fore. But Fury Road is a brilliantly feminist blockbuster which passes the Bechdel test with flying colours.
So light it's near flyaway, but grounded by canny casting and heartfelt performances, A Royal Night Out is a sugary shot of pure fantasy.
There are lightly delivered lessons for both parents and progeny; it nicely balances a message about allowing your kids to plough their own path with one about appreciating maternal sacrifice.
Man Up doesn't differentiate itself from the dregs of the genre as much as it might seek to but, in Bell's most modern of rom-com heroines, we've finally found a woman with whom many will chime.
What it lacks in originality and smarts it makes up for in excitement.
A hugely likeable, perfectly judged parody that provides empowering action and embarrassing incidents in equal measure.
The blue-skinned, miscellaneously misshapen boxtrolls are a triumph of design and painstaking execution, with their glow-in-the-dark eyes providing ample wow factor.
Efron may have finally found his calling as a sociopathic frat-boy and Rogen and Byrne make for an appealing couple, sharing ample comic chemistry.
Promises an exploration of memory and its relationship with identity but in the main delivers only superficial, yet admittedly stylish, thrills.
Santa Sangre has ample affection for outcasts and much to say about religious hypocrisy.
El Hosaini shows sensitivity to character and has a fresh, fluid style which imbues what could've been grim reality with optimism.
Features a celestial line-up of talking heads, with George Clooney, Johnny Depp and Matt Damon among the interviewees.
A charming and gently moving film.
This may be less flamboyant than some of Anderson's previous films but when it comes to complex, confounding drama he stands assuredly amongst the masters.
Quartet tugs confidently on the heart strings with the residents' fragile health and painful memories.
A more purely entertaining film you'd be hard pressed to find; Seven Psychopaths is best enjoyed as an unabashed hell-raiser that's also bloody funny.
Ultimately, by focusing on energetically edited footage of Stones at their musical peak, Morgen has made an immersive documentary that thoroughly entertains yet neglects to sufficiently enlighten.
Stunning and moodily atmospheric but dramatically sketchy, Dead Europe gives a mere snapshot of a continent falling to pieces and ultimately fails to bring its intriguing personal story to life.
Keyhole is an enchantment of chiaroscuro compositions which float across the screen like a dream; it's an acquired taste but pure cinema nevertheless.
If this is the future of film-making then basically we're all doomed.
At best it's an intermittent assault on the senses but even that's not nearly as fun as it sounds.
This is undeniably an admirable film but it would have benefited from a little more of the titular spirit.
Evil Dead has ample cheap shocks and few bloodcurdling frights but it builds to something gorily bravura and, if that's your bag, you'll come away satisfied.
An earnest, fundamentally likeable film which challenges us to question what we're told rather than calling us to arms.
Simon Killer eschews easy answers and obvious characterisation and it's all the more impressive because of it.
Inspired by the titular toy, Robosapien combines CGI and live action with fairly banal results.
The King of Marvin Gardens reminds us of the diversity and dynamism of the New Hollywood movement. And how odd it is that a largely forgotten film should feel so utterly unforgettable.
The writers never quite get under the skin of these characters, or fully to grips with the complexity of the situation.
Admission is disappointing rather than disastrous but it's desperately lacking in spark and individuality.
Although little is explicitly stated, the characters' back-story is effectively communicated - yet it's difficult to truly care.
That it triumphs, despite being a slave to formula, is squarely down to its uproarious banter, co-scripted by Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg and delivered with aplomb by an on-form ensemble.
It seems fitting that every frame should be rich with sorrow.
There's a distinct lack of individuality and insight and, appositely enough, if Lola Versus is about a woman floundering, as a film it can be accused of the same.
Brand is diffident and banal; he continues to lack versatility as an actor, seemingly more comfortable in his own skin.
Have we already found the worst film of the year?
Engrossing and enlightening but it doesn't quite live up to its considerable promise.
Das and Kapur make for effective sidekicks, it's pacy, fitfully funny and, in its determination to upend cultural expectations, likeably mischievous.
Entertaining but a touch slight, one thing that's in no doubt is that Treacle Jnr's heart is in the right place; it is, after all, a film named after a kitten.
Wildly inconsistent.
Not funny, quirky, or particularly insightful.
The Hunger Games largely transcends its teen-fiction origins to prove itself more than a money spinner.
The Bad and the Beautiful took home a quintet of Oscars from 1953's ceremony and in its title alone we have possibly the greatest ever description of Hollywood.
It's far from perfection but those who are more interested in consideration than carnage might find that such dignified imperfection will do.
With its hair-pulling, arse-baring and soul-selling it's often very funny and is certainly welcome respite from more saccharine takes on the subject matter.
A courageous, periodically unsettling coming-of-age tale, She Monkeys is the arresting first feature from director Lisa Aschan.
Although it fitfully drags, Sanders' confident handling of the sizable production means that overall it's an impressive debut.
Its young leads are terrific, the ruined city is a fitting backdrop for mental obliteration and the wall-to-wall parental negligence references the behaviour of the disinterested elite.
Rock of Ages is at best irresistibly idiotic and at worst brilliantly bad.
The aquatic terror is deftly balanced with lively, likeable characterisations.
Devoid of anything daring, Fast Girls makes some of the right motions but never rises above its cash-in status.
Feeble and cloying from midway to its final throes, it begins with a bang but - inappropriately for the scenario - goes out with a whimper.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Its jubilant anarchism intermittently excites, there's a smattering of well-executed gags and the cathartic violence set to euphoric tunes offers some (extremely) bad taste satisfaction.

While not quite funny enough to cut it as pure comedy, nor emotionally probing enough to be a great drama, The Players is still a pleasingly frank and, at times, guiltily daft take on a very sticky subject.
Ultimately, Comes a Bright Day offers insufficient excitement and - like its incompetent robbers - once it battens down those hatches the film has nowhere to go.
Man of Steel is short on the super, heavy on the morals and hardly a bold reinvention - yet as an(other) introduction to the titular do-gooder, it just about flies.
If Despicable Me 2 feels like little more than spectacular silliness, it's hard not to admire a film with such a canny grasp of what its young audience wants.
The action quickly becomes repetitive and del Toro and Travis Beacham's screenplay is so humourless and cliché-riddled that the cast buckle under the strain ...
A riveting and accomplished story of animal cruelty, corporate irresponsibility and nature striking back.
The Zero Theorem falls short of its promise: events don't raise the pulse or excite the mind and even the marvellous Waltz seems a little adrift.
Wes Anderson's eighth film dazzles and delights as if it has been liberated from the pages of a beautifully illustrated storybook.
Thomas makes for a competent if unspectacular feature director and the writing is characteristically sassy, even if it can't compete with the show's finest hours.
A story of musical chaos and mental instability that's often hilarious and ultimately really quite moving.
Nick Cassavetes' eighth film squanders its subversive premise. It's also rather hysterical and not in a comedic way.
Mia Wasikowska talks to camels in this well-meaning but flat-footed desert adventure.
An exposé of the music industry that takes superficially sinister turns yet lacks the comic chops or dynamism to amuse or excite.
By expertly embellishing the theatrical, Polanski has made Venus in Fur thrillingly cinematic.
For all its flaws Run & Jump is a big, cheery lummox of a film - one with a huge heart that's very difficult not to like.
This isn't a film that's particularly easy to enjoy but that doesn't mean that there isn't much here to admire.
If you've seen the trailer you've seen the best gags.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Equine capers abound in Benedikt Erlingsson's surprising and charming debut.
You'll need plenty of tissues, or a bucket. Or possibly both.

I Am Divine may not be the blowsy riot you'd expect given Divine's salty screen persona but it tells his story with wit, insight and compassion, revealing a rather sweet and sensitive man underneath that sparkling shell.
Zlotowski takes admirable risks, and the result is a flawed, provocative curio.
Lilting isn't a film of simple solutions and happy endings but, for all its sorrow, what it leaves you with is hope.
It's to the central quartet's credit that, although their ongoing adventures are stretching four fairly one-note characters just shy of snapping point, this time round it actually feels less tired.

Stevens visibly relishes every second of his blue-eyed bad boy's screen-time; it's a brilliantly perverse casting coup enhanced by Barrett's devilish dialogue, while Wingard directs with flamboyance and precision.
Excruciatingly intense and prone to explosions of violence.
Lucy is immensely inconsistent and exceedingly daft and yet it remains a good deal of fun.
In a movie where the title refers to the choice between the protagonist living and dying it's really not a great sign that you may find yourself willing her to go.
José Padilha's film has contemporary resonance and is different enough to the original, but unfortunately fails to distinguish itself from the corporate product it satirises.
A story those who live blithely in freedom quite simply need to see.
A worthy effort but Armstrong remains a tough nut to crack.
Vallée's sensitive direction ensures the relationship unfolds with credibility and, while tenderness between the pair might be fleeting, when it's glimpsed it packs a heavyweight punch.
Espinosa directs with nervous energy, combining blistering action with believable, sympathetic characters; this is assured, emotionally engaging stuff.
Wright directs with typical energy and effectively papers over an absence of plot.
An odd mix of formulaic thriller and true-life story, resulting in something sporadically successful but often uninspired.
Girl Most Likely is occasionally funny but it's a more formulaic film than you might expect from former documentarians.
Mister John might have the ingredients of a mystery but it's just too much of a puzzler to be truly satisfying.
Georges Franju's monstrous masterpiece delivers horror sans face but with a huge heart.
Funny, sad and sometimes strange, Prince Avalanche is an imperfect oddity that deserves an audience.
Enough Said is a match made in romantic comedy heaven - heart-warming and frequently hilarious.
Starred Up gives you a good sharp shake and, in doing so, truly opens your eyes.
Delivers romance that will lift your heart and tragedy that will bring tears to your eyes, underscored by a soundtrack that will most definitely stir your soul.
Gordon-Levitt shows promise as a director and his debut has bags of cinematic swagger.
Persiel's film entertains, but the nagging sense that it's mostly a ruse limits true engagement.
This fresh and rebellious quasi rom-com liberates the glamorous Olivia Wilde from the shackles of two-dimensional studio fare, reinventing her as a laidback tomboy involved in a romantic quadrangle.
What Utopia lacks in finesse it more than makes up for in passion.
The sequel lives up to its incendiary subtitle due to the quality of the material and the passion of its performers.
Fearless, relatable and beautiful, this is one of the year's best. Holding you so close for so long, you won't want to break free.
A winning mix of deadpan comedy, retro stylings and escalating insanity.
[Statham's] fans will no doubt have a blast. And this time it's highly likely that everyone else will too.

Gone is the original's frenzied urgency and, with the fundamental set-up remaining the same, if you're familiar with the 2003 film there's negligible suspense; it's a mystery thriller without the mystery.
A sexy, rollicking caper set in the late 70s which expertly infuses its criminality with both class and character, the latter delivered via a thick vein of askew humour.
Although some of its satire is rushed there's ample surreal drama and consistent comedic excellence from the already star cast ...
Who'd have thought that concrete would make such compelling subject matter?
The Program delivers an efficient overview of the scandal and builds tension despite the inevitability of the outcome.
Child 44 grows in stature and suspense as it gains focus, eventually revealing itself as a murky depiction of desperately unjust, fearful times.
Bill is an entertainingly irreverent biopic, enlivened by modern references and liberated by being less obliged to educate than its televisual predecessor.
This smart and sexy comedy comes cloaked in faux innocence; it's a glorious oddity which casts quite the spell.
Against a backdrop of frustrated creativity and censorship, Farhadi explores the relationship between art and life.
In the end, Raw turns out to be very well done as Ducournau serves up a tasty blend of gore, metaphor and mischief.
Positioning itself firmly at the arthouse end of horror, A Dark Song is a credible exploration of a desperately dysfunctional relationship.
Events are relayed with lashings of humour and romance, the sumptuous staging and showy camerawork fitting the flamboyant protagonist who's ill-suited to slumming it as a fugitive in the shadows.
It's nicely cast, pleasantly wistful and the scenes between Broadbent and an alternately genial and withering Walter are to be savoured.
Like Fast 7, the film is effortlessly snatched away by two squabbling action stars who know how to raise a smile: Johnson and Statham.
The whole enterprise is presented with such breathtaking panache, intricacy and humour that it's impossible to resist.
The film is a lot more entertaining when it cranks the histrionics all the way up to 11. Unfortunately, for the most part it's less camp, more crap.
Heal the Living is a film about death whose reverence for life can be found in every frame.
Screamingly funny and helmed with madcap energy by debut director Sean Foley, Mindhorn wrings an astonishing amount of enjoyment from the exploits of a spectacular fool.
Miss Sloane pivots entertainingly and it's fun watching a seasoned double-dealer rub up against more high-minded colleagues.
This sensationally strange, sometimes raucously enjoyable feature from Spain's Nacho Vigalondo only gets curiouser and curiouser as it goes on.
War Machine never feels like a mess, more an oddity; it might not say much that is new but it often says it in a way that hits home.

The excessive runtime, repetitive antics, cringeworthy cameos and tediously formulaic denouement means that a film that feels like a fun splash-about at the outset is itself in dire need of rescue by the end.
As witty and heartfelt as it is thrilling - a film that fangirls, fanboys and even those suffering from superhero fatigue can enjoy.
Although near-miss escape attempts deliver the expected tension and the end is a tad fudged, this is far more than a vehicle for cheap shocks.
The film has a fluid and psychologically penetrating feel, reframing the central dynamic as a shifting power play.
Although shot with grace by Coco before Chanel's Christophe Beaucarne, it's a film that never sweeps you up in the story.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As characters topple and tumble, float up in the air, hee-haw with laughter and feast on body parts, Slack Bay is speckled with hilarity.
Fluid photography and achingly honest performances merge magnificently, with the story of love amidst the livestock considerably more charming than it sounds.
Quibbles fall by the wayside like toppling trees. A tantalising establisher for a clash of the titans, this ably-directed actioner is monstrously entertaining.
Hawkins ... delivers a performance of dogged detail; she's a woman who seems to absorb every insult and disappointment in the stoop of her stance, the pain etched across her face.

The director documents her protagonists' struggles using compassion and deceptive artistry. Although she shows restraint in the moment, the film's simple and truthful humanity will resonate long afterwards.
It's a film that never seems to know what to make of its characters, eventually plumping for a quirky, feel-good climax that represents yet another departure from what came before.
This is dynamic filmmaking whose story finds modern resonance in the Black Lives Matter movement, showing how important it is that tales like this continue to be told.
Considering that this is Lowe's directorial debut (it's her second feature as screenwriter after the superb and not dissimilar Sightseers), Prevenge is remarkably well-realised.
It's a movie that explores the invigorating, engrossing impact of fiction - a beguiling creation that shows, appropriately enough, the way a great story can get right under the skin.
The film runs out of ideas long before its (modest) runtime is up. Still, devotees of facial hair and firearms are likely to have a blast.

Linklater's reverence for the everyday and the eloquence of his execution have made him a filmmaker for the ages, so this celebration of his achievements is welcome, even if it doesn't really do him justice.
Piling tragedy upon tragedy until it collapses under the weight, the fourth narrative feature from Derek Cianfrance makes a flagrant play for your heartstrings.

There is such warmth and wisdom in these women standing together, that what at first appears to be a story of unimaginable suffering quickly reveals itself to be a celebration of astonishing strength.
Jarmusch is at his most refined here, as he carefully chronicles the humble exploits of one of life's observers.
With a gripping story fashioned from indigenous culture and a satisfying blend of the familiar and the knowing, Moana represents yet another triumph in the studio's impressive recent run.
Teller demonstrates the requisite pluck, while Ciaran Hinds and Aaron Eckhart are cast against type as Vinny's father and his paunchy, balding coach.
Although the scenarios seem forced, the action feels natural thanks to the nonchalant delivery of a fine cast ...
Fervent in its telling and unusually cerebral, Silence is a paragon of integrity from one of modern filmmaking's most reliable maestros.
Sadly what transpires is stratospherically misjudged.
It's as gorgeous in its gloom as in its wonderfully shameless whimsy. It's a dizzying whirlwind of romance and sorrow, cinema to make you swoon.
Daringly intimate and unusually insightful, Jackie sees a South American provocateur take on an all-American idol - and the results are unforgettable.
Energised by a game performance and toe-tapping soundtrack, this is nevertheless a film that never really settles into a satisfying groove, nor confidently projects an identity.
The highlight ... is the sparkling screenplay, blending wry observation, provocative conversation and frequent hilarity.
Part rehash of the first film, part expansion of its bizarro universe, it treats its plot like a trifle, serving little more than to thread together some indecently entertaining action.
A film of rare empathy and shimmering beauty.
An outrageously enjoyable bitch-fest of a movie from writer-director Onur Tukel which ridicules the 'geriaction' phenomenon even as it revels in its tropes.
Arterton carries it along with her charisma and her subtle emoting elevates a film that too often plumps for the obvious.

12 Years a Slave is a film of searing sincerity and insight, whose central characters are drawn with real complexity. McQueen's third film doesn't just slide slavery under the microscope, it holds it there.

Harnessing the power of understatement, Nalwanga gives a wonderfully engrossing turn helped along by the sensitive camerawork, while an energetic Oyelowo and an estimable Nyong'o provide the classy support.
Often feeling closer to a long perfume advert than a drama, Song to Song is indisputably stylish but lacking in both impact and soul.
Tucci captures his subject from a range of interesting angles without ever resorting to po-faced portraiture himself.
It's all about McDormand - truly a performer you can build a whole film around, and one who can whisk a scene away from even her most seasoned peers.
A film as riotously funny as it is alarmingly pertinent.
The fluid visuals are a perfect match for the curiosity and exuberance of the kids, who prowl the motel grounds and beyond on the hunt for mischief.
If the Thor films have been a bit 'meh' thus far, by allowing Waititi room to do his genuinely eccentric thing, the 17th film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe might just be its best.
Despite his hulking frame, Vince has rarely gotten his hands dirty onscreen; here, he makes up for lost time.
Operating with an impeccable sense of restraint, Moretti has created a work of great sincerity and unshowy insight.
It's not for the easily offended. However the unlikely combination of ultra-violence and compassion may just slash its way to your heart.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Documents the rise and fall of a Brazilian kids' TV presenter in an explosion of colour, irreverence and excess.
movie_title: Bingo: The King of the Mornings (Bingo - O rei das manhãs) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The melancholic brand of machismo and Coster-Waldau's affecting turn never fail to mesmerise in a film that consistently foregrounds the human cost of crime.

As an actress, Palka is the very definition of game, while her freewheeling and intimate directorial style captures the chaos at close quarters, and she does well to stretch what seems like a novelty concept fruitfully to feature-length.
The cast spar splendidly, with Patricia Clarkson on spectacularly withering form.
The narrative serves up carefully balanced helpings of tears and laughter, showing a deep understanding of the father-daughter bond and the sometimes twisted roots of family.
If it doesn't get to the heart of what drives people to accumulate vast, unusable fortunes, it does show the vacuum of humanity this can leave behind.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Much can be forgiven due to its razzle-dazzle and the sheer pleasure of listening to Sorkin's target-obliterating dialogue - dialogue which Chastain and Idris Elba (playing Molly's lawyer) manage to make sound natural.
When The Post moves into its final act, Spielberg cranks up the tension magnificently and there are flourishes enough, even if the pay-off feels cringingly feel-good and then strangely flat.
Coco's sincerity is undeniable and its creativity often remarkable. The songs might be unlikely earworms but the film easily earns its place in your heart.
Director Wes Ball makes it a complete set and his ability to deliver punchy action and the occasional jolting jump-scare frightens some life into a predictable, albeit reasonably satisfying story.
Anderson's divine, poetically scripted and unpredictable melodrama examines the impact of emotional upheaval on the fragile mind of a finely tuned creative.
Yet it's The Walking Dead's Gurira who steals the show as the ferocious Okoye, gloriously swinging her spear in a billowing red gown.

That these men are brave beyond measure and saved countless lives is in no doubt but, with its focus on the dullest of details, lack of psychological insight and bizarre shifts in tone, it's a bewildering folly indeed.
It's remarkable how heartfelt each and every moment feels, without the film once descending into sentimentality.
It's unusual for a whodunnit to have such a powerful sedative effect as The Snowman.
It has ample promise for a debut and Beecham makes a persuasive pitch for star status.
Shannon, Jenkins, Spencer and Stuhlbarg are precision-cast but it's Hawkins that will steal your heart.
Stanley is superb, yet it is Wilson that will leave you shaken.
Candy-coloured, only fleetingly sentimental and with an embarrassment of mischievous energy, it's a bit like mainlining sugar.
Given its winning penchant for eccentric details and the blackest of humour, A Man Called Ove feels a shade sentimental in its final stretch; like its hero, it boasts a surprisingly big heart.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Smiths fans may well despair. And not in a way they'd enjoy.
A film that offers neither a contemporary twist on the well-worn conspiracy thriller, nor a satisfyingly meaty take on a true story.
Once again Nolan shows himself to be a master of pure cinema. Incomparably immersive, Dunkirk does admirable justice to its story - it's a film that never lets up, never surrenders.

The culture-clash comedy plays out with charming, sometimes toe-curling honesty and an acknowledgement of how complicated life can get when expectations weigh heavy and tradition unceremoniously intervenes.
The Messenger tries to cultivate character by laying the stylish tics on thick (distractingly askew camera angles, frequent flashbacks) but most of the elements are at odds.
Shamelessly smouldering from start to finish and letting its ladies have most of the fun, it's an ace actioner, in perfect tune with our age of disillusionment.
Soulfully scored and every bit as powerful in moments of discomforting silence, it's haunting indeed.
Rather like the casing that falls from the gunslinger's pistol, it has been stripped of impact, and hits the ground as an empty shell.
It has enough incendiary elements to grab your attention, but the mishmash of influences can't quite hold it.

Who knows whether there will ever be a time where the lives of black Americans seem like they actually matter, but it is the duty of filmmakers as formidable as Bigelow to keep reminding us they should.
Unfortunately this 'women go wild' movie comes with a twist. The twist being that it sucks.
As Patti spits out her lyrics - lewd, incendiary and eventually empowering - writer-director Jasper announces his own arrival with a great deal of swagger.
Wind River is a film that intermittently impresses, even if it keeps getting blown off course.
Cuesta does a competent job at the helm, delivering the occasional bravura flourish, but any punch and polish he brings to the table is undermined by the myriad failings of the script.
Even when Aronofsky doesn't have much to say, at least he says it with gusto.
The structure generates considerable suspense and Power keeps conventional horror histrionics to a bare minimum.
What should be desperately hard-going is rendered anything but by Haigh's delicate directorial style, an approach complemented by Plummer's appealingly understated performance.
Polite society and conventional femininity form a suffocating straightjacket in the eerily intoxicating Beast.
An enjoyably grimy, 80s-infused, Queens-set crime thriller about a bank robber busting his gut to free his incarcerated brother.
Attempts to shade in Ingrid and Dan's tragic backstories are cursory and more than a little clichéd, but so spot on is the satire that it's hard to imagine this being done better.
A textured portrait of the parent-child relationship, as well as a shrewd satire of corporate shenanigans.

The Ghoul embraces its low-budget Britishness - it's both dynamic and despondent, while Tunley makes strong use of its London locations as his protagonist pounds the capital's streets in a futile search for existential answers.
It's astutely judged, beautifully humane and, in its final throes, devastatingly romantic.
It looks the part and then some, yet lacks narrative vigour, intellectual weight, or any clear sense of what it wants to be or say.
A hoot from start to finish.
Rich with enchantment and fuelled by female determination, this story of the travails of an ordinary heroine is as delightful as its title suggests.
If it eventually surrenders to convention, Sleeping with Other People is still a refreshingly adult, often rule-breaking romantic comedy.
The imposition of a brutal jihadist regime is relayed with formidable articulacy and a surprising lightness of touch in this gut-wrenching drama from Mauritanian director Abderrahmane Sissako.

Like the best horror films It Follows will stay with you, making you look afresh at those trailing behind. It'll take you back to your own teenage years, reminding you what a terrifying world it can be when the adults step back.
The Gift is ostensibly about the power of an idea, but this thoughtful film encourages us to look afresh at our own behaviour and relationships.
Ant-Man marks the culmination of Marvel's "Phase Two" and they've brought the chapter to a close in likeable style.
For all its apparent earnestness, it's hard to shake the feeling that too many of the sharp edges have been shorn from this gut-wrenching story.
Fey throws herself into the showier role with admirable aplomb, but it's Poehler's quieter, more endearing turn that elevates the film beyond a whole-lotta-crazy.
Girlhood captures how wonderful it is to even briefly belong.
To describe The Revenant as epic hardly seems enough; magnificent is more like it.
Malachi lacks the chops to realise his admirable ambitions; his debut doesn't so much conk out, as never really get going.

This add-on to the Rocky franchise boasts a comparably deft mix of crowd-pleasing familiarity and freshness, particularly in the shape of its canny new casting - a combination that's set to excite a new generation of fans.
Evenly entertaining, although hardly essential viewing.

Deftly drawing out the moral compromises, obstructive complexities and unbelievable injustices of this risky business, the film manages to be entertaining and accessible as well as frighteningly credible.
An extraordinary paean to journalistic endeavour.

For some Capture the Flag will just about scrape by on its honourable intentions and brisk delivery; however, what seems on paper like a vaguely educational distraction, is merely another exercise in colourful chaos.
Hákonarson's film evolves into something increasingly compassionate, with matters culminating on a sincere, surprisingly moving note, that's both tender and tragic.
It extends its middle finger to the concept of suspension of disbelief with repeated fourth wall breaks, while the references come thick, fast and proudly unsubtle.
If Le Mépris lacks the uninhibited character of, say, Breathless, Pierrot le Fou, or Alphaville it undoubtedly makes up for it in emotional potency.
Utterly refreshing and even a little heartwarming, this story of a crabby old lady has vitality and swagger to spare.
Takes such paragons of festive mediocrity as The Family Stone, Christmas with the Kranks, Surviving Christmas and Love Actually and mashes them into a surprisingly palatable blend.
Spielberg should be applauded for coherently imparting a convoluted, international story and for skilfully showing how ideals can be compromised by the grip of paranoia.
It is a film that emphatically deserves to be in the mix come awards-time, from a director who knows that you don't need fast-paced action or expensive tricks to conjure truly spectacular cinema.
A detective story with a satisfying social justice twist.
Life depicts Dean as a sensitive, capricious creature, staring down his impending fame with paralysing foreboding.
This sassy, exhilarating monster mash will provide riotous entertainment for all but the faint-hearted.

This ferocious, masterful interpretation of the Scottish play lets rip with an onslaught of visual and emotional bravado, setting its story of ruthless ambition and spilt blood amid billowing smoke and red, raging fire.

A swirling, mutating apparition conjured from a crazed mind, this fluid and delirious film showcases a wealth of imagination as it drags us down through ever deeper, ever stranger layers of storytelling ...

It's a confrontationally violent and equivalently humane portrayal of life in a volatile country where absolutely everything can be lost in a heartbeat - your family, community and entire way of life.
It's a tale that remains woefully relevant, and that in the hands of these film-makers is, finally, unforgettable.
Martial arts fans will yearn for more action but this is a film that exercises restraint and prizes compassion, meaning those of a forbearing nature will see their patience pay off.
Intense and challenging it may be but it's a film that's rich with both empathy and insight.
If Citizen Kane is testament to a young man's genius then F For Fake is testament to a veteran's rebellious spirit and wicked sense of humour.
High-Rise is a feast of human depravity, flecked with blood, guts and filmmaking genius.
A Bigger Splash lives up to its title by being every bit as exuberant and refreshing as it sounds.

A film that wants to be the final word on haunted house horror, as its director embraces and finesses myriad genre tropes, cranking the spectacle up so far it's astonishing it shows no sign of the strain.
Bennett's screenplay is a delight, routinely enriched by his masterful and richly comical turn of phrase.
Fassbender is appropriately assertive as Jobs, showing the level of maniacal self-belief it takes to convince the world to buy what you are selling, and how that might impact on those around you.
It's easy to enjoy but hard to care about.
The focus moves fluidly around the key players, enriching the story, while the action is unflashy but precision-staged.
If the film lacks bite and panache, it's still true to the spirit of predecessors like Re-Animator and Zombieland in its fondness for wild horror and terrible taste laughs.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With a heart as big as its prehistoric creations, The Good Dinosaur is a likeable if lesser Pixar, a slightly lumbering beast that takes time to find its footing.

Whatever its flaws, films made with this much chutzpah last forever. Doctor Zhivago wears its daunting runtime like the lightest of shawls and, even after all these years, it's still worth surrendering your heart to.

The lack of an interesting new angle and the far-from-razor-sharp script means Stiller's dimwit routine feels stretched this time round and even his usually reliable rapport with Wilson seems deflated.
Its atypically modest brand of heroism is enough to guide it confidently home.
Fast, funny, if a little flimsy.
The be-true-to-yourself and don't-judge-others messages are nicely worked in: while it's robustly right-on, including being cheerfully feminist, it never feels preachy.
Achingly melancholic and philosophically ambitious, Anomalisa moulds reality into something genuinely magical.
The pair bounce so successfully off one another that this feels like a double act for the ages, in a film that actually deserves to spawn a sequel.

An earnest and entertaining look at stock market skulduggery, constricted by its adherence to genre convention and further comprised by its commercialism, Money Monster has two shining stars in front of the camera and one at the helm.
At best maintaining the meagre standard set by its critically mauled precursor, the heroes in a half-shell are back for a tonally obnoxious, patience-testing second outing.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Those of a wobbly disposition may find themselves momentarily lifted up, but they should be prepared to come back to earth with a bump.
Relevant, cogent and funny.
Adult Life Skills belies its homemade, careworn feel to present both a polished rib-tickler and a credible, intimate study of grief.
With white-hot performers at its fore and a screwball-style premise, Maggie's Plan promises more than it ultimately delivers but there's abundant fun to be had along the way.

Frank and fairly explicit, the events nevertheless unfold through a prism of sensitivity and compassion, with Husson sidestepping the sensationalism suggested by the provocative title and subject matter.
The emphasis on female perspectives gives modern resonance to an adaptation that simultaneously has oodles of time for the traditional.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kim feels substantially drawn thanks to Fey's sterling work, but Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is much less successful in the portrayal of its supporting players, many of whom are amalgamations of real people.
Little Men has a lightness of touch which belies its formidable powers of observation; frequently insightful and superbly performed, it presents us with a rainbow of recognisable humanity.
It's a well-meaning, often superbly acted film with nothing very original to say.
This film offers something a bit different from traditional biopics.
Cruz keeps things engaging but she's really up against it in a film that's mawkish, melodramatic and sometimes comically misjudged.
Fun references and welcome cameos add to the appeal of a film that's much more successful in its stupidity than when it strives to be smart.
By attempting to appease traditionalists and newcomers in equal measure, The Legend of Tarzan has compromised itself into anonymity.
The result is a film whose narrative minimalism may frustrate, but whose core performances and visual majesty convey all that's left unsaid.

Amponsah's access and the intimacy of his insights make the film deeply personal, but carefully drawn out wider resonances mean that it doubles as a compassionate portrait of black masculinity in crisis.
The tone remains meticulously respectful as Björkman delivers a discerning appraisal of an endlessly intriguing, frequently contradictory individual.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mackenzie's tenth feature cultivates great compassion for its characters, while making wider points relating to exploitation and community erosion well.
Adhering so closely to the book results in a fan-pleasing adaptation that stays obediently on track, even if that means delivering us to an all-too predictable destination.

The White King isn't especially thought-provoking, nor sophisticated enough to win over accompanying adults. Regardless, the combination of brutality-lite, high jinks and life lessons may be enough to satisfy older kids.
Far from preaching to the converted, this sequel winningly subverts the traditional college comedy while remaining authentically ribald.

X-Men is a franchise that can coast on the considerable appeal of its suitably extraordinary ensemble, but even these actors can't distract from the fact that this well has run desperately dry of ideas.

The lack of scope for emotional engagement and unoriginal feel means it'll likely be a distant memory by bedtime but, in the moment at least, this reasonably well-oiled enterprise has just enough spark.
Sing Street blends relatable strife, young love and cheering acts of rebellion into a funny and foot-tapping treat.
The film is haunting in its stillness and strangeness. The exact nature of what unfolds is best left to find out for yourself. But do you dare?
Solidly watchable, even if the characters remain frustratingly unknowable.
Saulnier has created a film as exhilarating as it is excruciating.
This courageous film gets right up in the face of suffering and it doesn't flinch.
This unusual take on love and loss is notable for its almost surprising sincerity and elevated by its unforgettable peculiarity.
The film is Hiddleston's by a hair but Olsen very nearly steals it out from under him.
A rural community is asked to forgive a shocking crime in Swedish director Magnus von Horn's quietly charged feature debut.

Farr's handling of the themes is desperately unsubtle, the relationship between the central couple is frustratingly underdeveloped, and the film's melodramatic tendencies are at odds with its ice-cool visuals.
This sumptuous story of an incompetent songbird will warm your heart as surely as it hammers at your eardrums.

It sometimes plays like a bizarre parody. It can be pretty entertaining once you've retuned your expectations, although it lurches into appallingly offensive territory in the form of some of Banning's take-down quips.
Overstuffed, fidgety and fearful, it's a blockbuster for the less flattering features of our time.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's an insightful and stylish riff on the old adage: just because you're paranoid doesn't mean they're not really out to get you.
[A] terrific platform for Wiig's deadpan comedic skills ...
A perfect example of cinema's capacity to confront evil.
The female lead gives it fire power, but Jane Got a Gun is far from a crack shot.
Finding a certain majesty in the murk, The Absent One is unashamedly derivative but remains a class act regardless.

This is fun, visually interesting, two-fingers-in-the-air filmmaking which, in its compassion for those lonely souls on society's fringes, reminds us that even the most scathing of satire needn't be heartless.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although Eye in the Sky offers up a range of views and an impressively balanced picture, there's no denying its "every life matters" message.
Too inconsistent to make good on its, admittedly, honourable intentions.
If it's short on swagger, the film at least has the legs to keep things pacey and eventful throughout its trim 92-minute duration.
Enjoy it before the English language version comes out.
The only thing which would make this film more awkward is watching it with your parents.
The Greatest Showman is earnest, joyful, not bad enough to be bad, but not good enough to be the next Rent.

Dolan's sixth feature lacks the humour and poignancy of previous efforts, and Ulliel's brooding enigma is a frustrating focus, with the more intriguing depictions of human frailty being those surrounding him.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The talking-head format may be shopworn, but it rarely undermines this infectious, insightful look at the fickleness of pop stardom.

With arguably the most incredible colours and landscapes ever been committed to film, Samsara forms consistently coherent episodes that show how, even when other cultures may appear alien, everything is connected.

Circumstance may miss out on making a truly startling political point, but it is a thoroughly enjoyable and tautly executed tale of young love, forbidden fruit and the world previous generations leave behind for us.
Surprisingly unpredictable, N.F.A. has its share of mopey interludes, but ends up unexpectedly close to home.
With something to relate to in everyone, Happy, Happy is a fun dose of laughter, excitement and spontaneity with added hidden layers that is more than a little infectious.
Set Fire To The Stars, like Dylan Thomas himself, has the ability to stir your deepest emotions.
You'll long for a slightly smoother animation style (Pixar won't be quaking in their boots), but this surprisingly fun yarn will undoubtedly have youngsters reaching for the nearest guitar.
Ferdinando's Michael Logan was never going to rival Ryan Gosling's Driver or Kim Bodnia's Frank, but the comparisons to both Drive and the Pusher trilogy are inescapable.

Considerably better than its predecessor, the central four may give it their all but the people behind this franchise sadly don't seem all that interested in their crime-fighting, pizza-eating heroes.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: All in all, a good summer movie.
Bound by Flesh is an excellent documentary.
Healey has very consciously attempted to avoid catering to the male gaze, and (no surprise here) the film is all the better for it.
Jacquet's obvious reverence for his subject turns the propagation of a species into a grand love story.
A stunning piece of visual poetry that will, hopefully, be remembered as one of the most important stories to be told in Australia's film history.
With its script and storyline, I'm not certain that The Mountain Between Us could have worked well for any actors in the roles.
Ducat's documentary provides viewers with an insightful look into the world of a man who was dealt a bum hand, seemingly, from birth.
movie_title: All Me: The Life and Times of Winfred Rembert (2012)

Woody Allen regresa a su mejor forma con un oscuro drama sobre la ambición, el deseo, la obsesión, y el papel que juega la suerte en el destino de las personas.
Un relato extraordinario, revelador de la naturaleza humana (y animal), a medio camino entre el registro documental y el realismo poético.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Sin llegar al nivel de las anteriores, esta tercera parte entretiene aunque está más basada en la acción que en sus personajes, rasgo fuerte de la saga.
Un entretenimiento de primer nivel, muy divertido y bien realizado, que juega con las convenciones de la comedia policial trasladadas a ambiente porteño.
Un pequeño film de emociones contenidas sobre cómo es crecer, madurar y enamorarse a la sombra de una tragedia familiar.
Un drama familiar previsible, inofensivo y hermosamente fotografiado, con buen elenco y poco más a destacar.
Definitivamente no para todos los gustos, esta violenta y asombrosa película coreana promete convertirse en una de las verdaderas sorpresas del año.
Kusturica se repite a sí mismo y entrega una alocada comedia sobre el amor, la locura y la guerra.
Un film de acción que no da respiro, no tiene mayores pretensiones que la de entretener, y cumple con todo lo que promete. El mejor de la serie, sin duda.
Una película irónica y romántica, con lujos de ambientación y fotografía, fiel al espíritu de la novela de Jane Austen en que se basa.
Una película conmovedora, sugestiva y poética, donde gran parte de la convicción proviene de sus increíbles actores no profesionales.
La animación de Pixar se supera, una vez más, a sí misma, aunque no mantenga la frescura narrativa ni la originalidad de historia y personajes de sus mejores películas.
Un thriller menor que probablemente aburrirá a quienes hayan leído la novela y aturdirá con su confusa trama a quienes no sepan nada de la historia.
A pesar de su extensa duración, la película no parece tener un minuto de sobra. El relato es apasionante, y está servido por un actor-director que ha aprendido mucho de sus maestros.

Wim Wenders y Sam Shepard (Paris, Texas) recuperan (en excelente fotografía y mejor música) una iconografía norteamericana al servicio de una historia sobre el desarraigo y la necesidad de recuperar vínculos largamente perdidos.
Un drama intimista e inquietante que esconde una reflexión perturbadora sobre un vergonzoso capítulo de la historia francesa. Brillante dirección y actores.
Un retrato honesto y revelador de la descomposición de un matrimonio, visto desde la perspectiva de los hijos adolescentes.
Pedro Almodóvar regresa a terrenos familiares: La Mancha, la comedia, la fortaleza femenina y, por supuesto, Carmen Maura. Un regreso esperado y satisfactorio.
Una película sensible y disfrutable sobre las relaciones entre padres e hijos y la construcción de una individualidad, a pesar de las semejanzas.

Un policial interesante y algo original, con comentario socio-político incluido. Al final le sobran facilismos y algunos cabos sueltos, pero las buenas actuaciones y la mano del director lo compensan.
Un film incómodo y desafiante sobre cuestiones plenamente vigentes en el mundo de hoy, que dejará insatisfechos a quienes busquen sólo entretenimiento.
Un baldazo de realidad que confirma a los hermanos Dardenne como dos sensibles observadores de personajes marginales.
Un film duro, polémico y bien realizado, que promueve el debate sobre un conflicto aún por resolver.
Una película frívola y superficial sobre un tema serio e importante como el tráfico de armas. Entretiene, pero como denuncia cínica se queda corta.
Un policial moderadamente efectivo y bien realizado, alejado por completo de la estética de la serie televisiva original. Intrascendente.
Un drama intimista sobre el peso del pasado, la soledad, y la necesidad de sanar heridas profundas. Excelentes actuaciones de Sarah Polley y Tim Robbins.
Meryl Streep brilla en esta comedia romántica graciosa y disfrutable sobre el amor, los prejuicios, y otras costumbres muy humanas.
Una adaptación que no hace un gran esfuerzo por disimular su origen teatral y se sostiene gracias a un buen elenco y algunas sorpresas.
Una comedia dramática con iguales dosis de picardía y emotividad, sostenida en dos buenas actuaciones de Judi Dench y Bob Hoskins.
Estupendo retrato de una personalidad compleja y fascinante que vale por sí mismo, más allá de la formidable caracterización de Philip Seymour Hoffman.
Quienes busquen lo más parecido a una pesadilla a cambio del precio de una entrada, saldrán bastante satisfechos.
Imposible dejar de pensar en la asombrosa transformación, tanto física como emocional, a la que se sometió Penélope Cruz para encarnar a su Italia (...)
(...) Aún con su intensidad a medio camino, The Woodsman es un drama maduro, desafiante y revelador de lo que estamos dispuestos a tolerar y/o a perdonar (nos) los seres humanos.
Wong Kar-wai confirma, por si hacía falta, que es uno de los cineastas más precisos e integrales de la actualidad.
Esa película de terror dentro de la película ocupa la menor parte del metraje, lo cual es una lástima porque es la parte más interesante.
El Jardinero Fiel es una de esas películas que importan más que nada por su tema (...)
Uno está dispuesto a perdonarle todos sus facilismos porque, en términos cinematográficos, es un muy buen drama.
Jackson peca de la misma megalomanía que estiró y arruinó parcialmente los últimos 45 minutos de El Regreso del Rey (...)
(...) Niels Mueller (...) conduce el relato con seguridad y tensión creciente hacia el inevitable estallido de violencia final.
Una Vida Iluminada ya es suficiente carta de presentación como para esperar más del Liev Schreiber director que del actor.
Yesterday es un drama sobrio y emotivo sobre los sacrificios de una mujer en medio de la pobreza, la adversidad y la discriminación.
Lo más reciente del canadiense David Cronenberg es un sólido thriller, casi de factura clásica, sobre las ramificaciones de la violencia.
Rutinaria adaptación de un best-seller sobre temática exótica, con lujos de fotografía, vestuario, dirección de arte y hasta música que no disimulan un argumento cursi y previsible.
Si uno está dispuesto a atravesar el ropero de la imaginación, Narnia puede ser una magnífica aventura llena de magia, emoción y fantasía.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Una aventura cómica y liviana, que se beneficia de la imaginación visual del director Terry Gilliam.

Jim Jarmusch vuelve a sorprender con una película minimalista donde los pequeños detalles, varios personajes episódicos, y un casi imperturbable Bill Murray, nos conducen hacia una travesía extraña y sugestiva.
Una épica historia de amor narrada con profunda sensibilidad y maestría; gran actuación de Heath Ledger. Tal vez el primer gran clásico del siglo XXI.
Una comedia dramática moderadamente disfrutable si bien previsible, donde Toni Collette y sobre todo Shirley MacLaine elevan el interés.
Una comedia dramática absolutamente menor, con personajes potencialmente atractivos pero finalmente inverosímiles y estereotipados.
Entre la complejidad casi documental de su trama y su impecable ejecución cinematográfica, las casi tres horas de duración no se sienten.
Una biografía más bien convencional y algo superficial, que vale la pena más que nada por la labor de sus protagonistas y por la música de Johnny Cash.

Un valioso testimonio sobre una época controversial (con inquietantes referencias a la actual política de Estados Unidos), filmado en extraordinario blanco y negro y con estupenda labor de David Strathairn.
Caetano ha hecho un film de suspenso, no una denuncia política, que funciona muy bien sobre todo en sus minutos finales.
Un tenso e interesante thriller político, si bien abrumador y por momentos confuso, sobre tema actual, con destacada labor de George Clooney.
Una comedia más bien "seria" que no busca tu risa fácil sino que pases un rato entretenido junto a personajes humanos y creíbles a los que les pasan cosas humanas y creíbles.
Una película liviana y disfrutable, sinceramente menor, que apuesta más al espíritu adolescente de sus protagonistas que al drama de fondo de sus personajes.
Típico asunto de receta (con mensaje moral solapado) que pretende sorprender con supuestas "vueltas de tuerca" pero apenas logra entretener.
Una película "linda" si bien edulcorada, y demasiado directa hacia lo que se supone que el espectador debe sentir. Sólo falta el cartel al final: "échale sal a tu vida".
A pesar de la poca innovación, esta segunda parte es casi tan divertida como la primera, sobre todo gracias a un estupendo personaje llamado Scrat.
El director toca fondo con una fábula para adultos tan ridícula como pretenciosa. Solo Paul Giamatti logra mantener a flote este fiasco.
Como toda confesión, en la que alguien desnuda su intimidad sin pudor para quien quiera escuchar, Tarnation es capaz de generar desde la fascinación curiosa hasta la incomodidad y el rechazo.
Una película bien intencionada aunque imperfecta sobre la identidad individual más allá de lazos familiares, nacionalidades, religión o raza.
movie_title: Va, Vis et Deviens (Live and Become) (Go, See, and Become) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Un drama familiar intimista y bien actuado sobre los efectos que puede producir un trauma en la vida de las personas, y sobre la oportunidad de cambiar.
Mel Gibson propone una discutible aproximación a la civilización maya que es, ante todo, un intenso relato de acción y heroísmo.
Un drama urbano duro y conmovedor, si bien algo previsible, con un estupendo protagonista. Una película realmente atendible que nos acerca al infrecuente cine sudafricano.
Un drama inteligente, tenso y reflexivo sobre la insatisfacción, el deseo, la infidelidad y las perversiones de un puñado de habitantes suburbanos. Excelente dirección y elenco.
Una película lúcida y algo desconcertante sobre los deseos y fantasías de un trío de mujeres en vacaciones, con el trasfondo de la dura realidad haitiana del régimen de Duvalier.
Una película de sobrecogedora belleza que se las arregla para arrojar nueva luz sobre un tema trillado y recurrente.
Rocky se retira con dignidad en este broche de oro de una saga que %u2013con sus puntos altos y bajos- debe considerarse un triunfo personal en la carrera de Sylvester Stallone.
Una comedia romántica realmente menor y predecible, con alguna ironía sobre la música pop de los años '80 (y la de ahora).
Un crudo relato sobre el movimiento independentista irlandés que confirma a Ken Loach como cineasta comprometido con la historia reciente y las injusticias.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Una estupenda reconstrucción histórica y un atractivo tratamiento visual son los principales valores de esta interesante aunque irregular adaptación.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Un drama urbano muy contemporáneo que explora superficialmente ciertas realidades sociales, pero que presta más atención a las crisis domésticas de sus personajes. Podría haber sido mucho más interesante.
Como adaptación de un cómic al cine, 300 es visualmente impactante. Pero una vez que uno se acostumbra queda sólo la historia, y allí no hay nada nuevo, original, ni sorprendente.
Un atractivo y bien logrado ejemplo de cine negro donde se mezclan glamour y misterio, con estupendo elenco y excelente recreación de época y atmósfera.

No es ni una comedia, ni una tragedia, ni una historia de amor, ni una fábula. Es ni más ni menos que una idea original mal desarrollada, que no entretiene lo suficiente y que conduce a ninguna parte.
Una notable mirada a la vida bajo un régimen opresivo, en este caso la RDA de 1984. Sorprendente debut del director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, con excelente elenco y calidad narrativa.
Entre la sátira, la fábula y el comentario crítico (...) el interés se pierde y no convencen.
Un retrato íntimo e interesante en el que lo más sobresaliente es, por lejos, la sobria composición de Helen Mirren.
Un thriller más bien mediocre, inverosímil y rebuscado que pretende sorprender al espectador con una vuelta de tuerca final... igualmente mediocre, inverosímil y rebuscada.
Una exploración muy personal, muy íntima y para nada condescendiente sobre la proximidad de la muerte a edad temprana. Muy buen elenco.
La despedida de Robert Altman no está entre lo mejor de su obra, pero es una cálida evocación de tiempos y ritos pasados animada por un atractivo elenco.
Un thriller fuera de lo común, que prioriza la investigación y la acumulación de pistas sobre la acción y el suspenso.
Un retrato crudo y humano %u2013filmado en riguroso blanco y negro- sobre pequeños y grandes actos de rebeldía frente a las injusticias.
Yo no sé si habrá una Shrek 4, pero si el ingenio y el sentido de la diversión se mantienen no me importaría en absoluto volver a visitar ese reino muy, muy lejano.
Una película fresca, reveladora, emotiva, graciosa, encantadora, que se disfruta como un viaje o como un viejo libro que nos han dejado guardado para abrir, por primera vez, en el momento justo.
Un entretenimento de primer nivel, con extraordinaria animación pero sobre todo con entrañables personajes y una historia original, divertida y hasta raramente emotiva.
La adolescencia le sienta bien a Harry Potter y sus compañeros en esta quinta entrega de la serie, en la que hay emoción, romance, humor, fantasía, terror y extraordinarios efectos visuales.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Después de Match Point (su mejor película de los últimos años), Woody Allen regresa a un cine menor, olvidable, sin mayores pretenciones que divertir durante un rato.
Un brillante duelo actoral entre Judi Dench y Cate Blanchett %u2013dos de las mejores actrices de la actualidad- que es también un sutil estudio sobre la soledad y la obsesión.
Por su humanidad y fuera desmitificadora, además de su rigurosa ejecución cinematográfica, se suma con honores a lo mejor de la filmografía de un gran director.
Una lujosa producción que, a nivel dramático, tiene la misma profundidad que una telenovela. Eso sí: hay (alguna) buena música y una inusual actuación de Eddie Murphy.
Una sátira inteligente, oportuna, ambigua y bien actuada, pero mucho menos graciosa y menos polémica de lo que prometía.
La sorprendente composición de Felicity Huffman es el principal atractivo de esta road movie agridulce.
Un irónico vistazo a los vericuetos del poder y la justicia, mucho menos interesante de lo que se esperaba. La estupenda Isabelle Huppert levanta el interés.
Un tenso y atrapante relato que imagina, con un realismo casi documental, lo que pudo haber sucedido a bordo del fatídico vuelo.
Una mirada tierna y desinhibida a los conflictos, los temores, los fracasos y las esperanzas de una familia, con estupenda banda sonora y elenco.
(...) Una celebración original y festiva que confirma el bizarro talento de su creador.
Una película entrañable y conmovedora sobre la amistad y la solidaridad entre dos mujeres, con dos estupendas actrices.
Lo mejor de esta fascinante y extraña película es todo lo que dispara en el espectador en su intento por encontrarle un significado.
Un documental contundente y alarmante que, de la mano de un preocupado y convincente Al Gore, se convierte en un verdadero llamado a la acción.
(...) Difícil recordar un thriller con tan poco diálogo, en el que los silencios y las contemplaciones sean mucho más importantes que los enunciados de los personajes.
El oficio del director Richard Donner convierte a este policial de rutina en un digno entretenimiento. Ni más ni menos.
Christopher Nolan presenta la rivalidad entre dos magos como si se tratara de un vistozo y complejo truco de magia cuyo secreto nos es develado.

No está entre lo mejor de Scorsese, pero es un buen policial con algunos momentos intensos, una vertiginosa narración casi sin pausas, y un estupendo elenco (a pesar de Jack, que excede su personaje).
El Nacimiento es el equivalente cinematográfico de una tarjeta postal de Navidad, o de un inocente pesebre viviente. Es tan prolija como fría e impersonal.
