Got a David Lynch jones? Then you'd do well to check this one out because it's straight up Twin Peaks action...
Sleepless is full-force Argento.
Dead or Alive isn't for anyone who can't take the gruesome stuff...
If you're down for a silly hack-and-slash flick, you can do no wrong with Jason X.
[Raimi's] matured quite a bit with Spider-Man, even though it's one of the most plain white toast comic book films you'll ever see.
Neglecting YOUR bedmate? Well, this entertaining and well-made short will make you think twice about that.
This is just something you're gonna have to see for yourself.
One of the most shocking Japanese horror films ever
It's a regoddamndiculous idea and I like it!
So this is a new challenge of sorts - to find the hidden movie in "Haute Tension."
Horror plays out quite like an episode of Freddy's Nightmares.
Who is this guy ... Forrest Gump or something?
Barrel Entertainment has done it again.
movie_title: Last House on Dead End Street (1977)

movie_review_blurb: This film is basically one big Scooby Doo episode.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It turns my stomach when I hear that a musician takes himself so seriously that he thinks can change the world.
You get the feeling that the filmmakers did their homework and that they're here to represent a harsh reality."
And as with the first film, this one also leaves you wanting hours more once those end credits begin flashing across the screen.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

It's not quite on the same level as The Conjuring (one of the scariest films in recent memory), but it's also far from the cash grab, low-rent spin-off that it could have been.
Entirely hollow, poorly put together, and will require an audience on its level of stupidity to survive. Don't be one of its supporters.
One of the most entertaining, fun, thrilling, heartfelt and beautiful summer blockbusters we've seen.
Much like the first movie, The Purge: Anarchy sets up a surprisingly interesting scenario and world, but simply bungles its execution.
Comes across as small, uneven, and, at times, lazy.
A tonal mess that suggests the filmmakers were never quite sure exactly what they wanted from the movie.
Once the supernatural elements begin to dig their claws in too deeply, the film turns into every single generic exorcism movie you've seen sine The Exorcist.
Like a ship that can't seem to get that perfect gust of wind to hit its sails.
Overall, a very worthy follow-up.
It's surprising how quickly the worst elements of the film began to stack up, and do their part to tear the whole thing down.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Million Dollar Arm ... can never outrun the fact that its basic approach to its subject matter is flawed.
Stale, flat, and completely underwhelming.
Finds its success in meaningful themes, character-driven story, and smart execution, and ultimately creates some impressive depth for the phenomenon franchise.
Gondry's unique vision makes Mood Indigo pop like no other filmmaker could.
Too much time is dedicated to both bad jokes and funny jokes that are allowed to overstay their welcome and ultimately implode.
A special film. It's bombastically entertaining and action packed, but it doesn't disregard emotion and story. And it's a fitting follow-up that will make lovers of the Road Warrior giddy.
The Secret World of Arrietty is a nice piece of kiddy fluff, but it's a beautiful, well-told piece of kiddy fluff.
A fine, tension-filled, intelligent thriller from an exciting emerging filmmaker.
A feature that is filled with boxing tropes and, more than anything, just feels entirely dull.
The film is everything anyone could want from a comic book movie, and will stand as one of the best of all time.
A better than average caper with some really great performances and unique style that also further expands on the breadth of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
One of the most affecting works Pixar has produced yet, and absolutely one of their best titles.
While not exceptional, Jurassic World satisfies as a fun summer blockbuster that will get audiences excited to see dinosaurs on the big screen again.
Chapter 3 doesn't add enough to the big picture, and overall feels misguided.
A less-than-basic disaster film with no emotional weight.
The message of the movie is admirable and well-woven in, but as a film, it is taken down by its messiness.
We will be very lucky if we get another movie either as good or better this year.
[Love & Mercy is] how to do a biopic right.
The most over-the-top sequences the filmmakers could imagine, and each one is as fun as the last.
A gorgeous re-imagining, bringing to life the specific beauty and charm of the fairy tale. But it's also rather hollow, doing little to add its own spin.
It's not as smart as you want it to be, but it's a lot smarter than the worst examples of the genre.
The movie isn't revolutionary and doesn't aim to create a whole new wave of silent filmmaking, but it is a fun diversion.
Another "Chosen One" story that really feels drawn out and convoluted, crumbling into something tiresome and tedious.
A rather sweet love story following two characters who have seen war alter their perspective on the world.
Blackhat does have a good amount going for it, [but] it also can't outrun its major issues.
A tremendously powerful performance at its center from an incredibly talented actor truly brings A Most Violent Year alive, and makes it a film to remember.
Its central flaw of having an unwatchable protagonist is simply too massive to ignore, and sours everything that comes as an extension of it.
So entertaining and deeply satisfying that you're immediately struck with the desire to reenter the world as soon as the movie ends.
A beautiful, deep, psychological thriller that comes together with fantastic performances.
Doesn't quite live up to its predecessor, but, all the same, is still an immensely funny, witty caper.
An entertaining family movie, a true Sam Raimi film, and a fun return to a merry old land.
A vehicle for four extremely talented actors to spend some time crafting interesting characters with great dialogue.
If it were any other director at the helm of Trance it would be a more impressive film, but instead it's one of Boyle's more mediocre efforts.
Buy a ticket, enjoy watching ninjas on zip lines and The Rock kicking ass, and when the lights go up try to avoid thinking about it on any deeper level.
If this is what Park Chan-wook can bring to the American film world, then hopefully he will stay for a very long time.
One of the most refreshingly creative zombie movies in recent memory.
Even as one of his weaker efforts, Django Unchained still ranks higher than most of what comes out over the course of a year.
There's no point in remaking a film unless you can improve upon the execution of an original idea and/or reform an old idea and make it apply to the now; Red Dawn doesn't bother to do either.

he film does have some interesting choreography and the props department outdid themselves when it came to weapons, but the only reason to focus in on that stuff is because the rest of the movie is so unimpressive.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: With his film Mendes not only resurrects 007, but makes the character's defining trademarks make more sense in a modern world
Slow down the number of demonic spirit movies, start thinking twice before settling on the "kids are scary" idea again, and start coming up with something new.
The final product is a mixed bag and you may not like yourself for being entertained by it, but at least it's original.
Butter has strong moments and has more than a few good jokes, but as a whole it struggles to keep its footing
Alex Cross is a total trainwreck. You'd think it would be hard to mess up something as simple as a cop vs. killer story this badly, but Cohen and his crew seem to screw it up at every turn.
As fresh as a twelfth inning ballpark hot dog and half as entertaining.
Intense, gripping, funny, and absolutely fantastic.
I'm certain that there are still creative, interesting stories to be told based around the idea of demonic possession, but this one can barely be considered an effort.
A serious drama about hidden truths and family, the film works hard to earn its emotional depth and thanks to a compelling story, well-drawn characters, and terrific performances it succeeds.
The film has one of the most bizarre dick joke to earnestness ratios ever, but strangely it all works and is, most importantly, hilarious.
It's overdone and chock full of dumb, but if approached with the proper mindset it could end up being one of the better surprises of the summer.
The movie is completely tone deaf - unsure if it's a horror movie, a comedy or a drama - and never finds anything interesting in the characters for the audience to latch on to.
You'll be impressed by the approach; awed and spellbound by the philosophy; and immediately compelled to seek out more about the brilliant and enigmatic subject at its center.
I procrastinate because I care and because writing reviews of movies you love is hard. And I really loved Martin McDonagh's Seven Psychopaths.
It embraces the universe it lives in without exploiting it or letting it weigh down the story, and offers its hero a personal, dangerous challenge without ever losing its popcorn charm.
It's hard to imagine that a funnier movie will come out this year.
...while the movie's plot isn't wholly original, it's the filmmaker's approach and the story's outcome that makes the movie worthwhile.

With the exception of a few detrimental flaws, the remake actually plays with some legitimately interesting, different ideas that come together to create an attention-worthy entry in the science-fiction genre.
The movie doesn't fully live up to all of these promises, but is still a satisfactory adventure worth exploring.
It doesn't just execute one cliché-ridden idea - it executes three.
Makes no effort to try anything new and instead seem content to let the genre slip into staleness.
In The Wolf of Wall Street, Scorsese recognized a story of insanity, lewdness, depravity, greed and incredible entertainment value, and that's exactly what he has brought to the screen.
The movie is at times funny, brutal, exciting, and raw, and with a special splash of science-fiction it delivers an emotionally honest, deep look at what it means and how it feels to be in love.
Inside Llewyn Davis is unlike anything the directors have made and is a phenomenal piece of art.
Boldly builds on the world first seen in Gary Ross' 2012 film.
How much better it could have been with a less strict, by the book approach?
Feels like it was made by people who saw Wall Street and Rounders and thought they were just too damn exciting.
Damon once again shows why he is one of the best lead actors we have.
Maybe we should have left this franchise where it started.
Armed with blistering performances, an engaging narrative and some stunning cinematography and direction, it may very well end up being one of the best of the year
Levine's skills can't completely transform what is a severely underwhelming script.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's rare to find a film that really works on all levels, but that's exactly what Denis Villeneuve's has constructed with Prisoners.
As a sequel, Cloudy With A Chance of Meatballs 2 doesn't fully stack up to the original, but it's impressive just how close it actually gets.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Part of me wants to support this franchise on the grounds of how rare it is for an original science-fiction concept to get a full trilogy of theater-released feature films, but Riddick makes that damn near impossible.

Much like the first movie, The Smurfs 2 is exclusively filled with humor targeted at the very youngest members of the audience, leaving grown-ups no option other than to cover their faces with their palms and shake their heads.
The movie may not fully deliver on many of its themes, but it does hit squarely on the man vs. beast battle that exists within Logan.
Despicable Me 2 feels more like a first draft than a final product.
It's realistic in approach and honest in emotion, but also wonderfully fantastical and cinematic. The future is bright for the Man of Tomorrow.
Uses absolutely stunning art to tell an impressive story about both a crucial period in Japanese history and what true passion can accomplish.
A straightforward premise, but it's one that's executed with naturalism, surprising wit, and fantastic style.
Shot beautifully, and with a fantastic sense of wonder within the world being created, which translates to big-screen magic
Bahrani does an excellent job of taking the conflict and running with it - though simple issues in choices and approach prevent 99 Homes from being great.
It's poorly made, tired, insultingly simplistic, and a real waste of the talented people who are involved with it.
While the sequel doesn't pack the full punch of the original, it's a wonderful follow-up that is richly dense in detail and features a parade of thrilling and fun surprises.

It's unique creative spirit alone makes it a film well worth discovering and exploring, and while it's only getting a small release to start with, it's a film that will and most definitely should find an audience that will love it.
'Gifted' is a sweet, charming bit of storytelling that has something to say and says it well.
Save a few bright spots, it culminates as a mess.
The movie is most certainly a genre film fan's delight: equal parts smart and mean.
The movie is as legitimately fun as it is thrilling, and it simultaneously generates excitement about for futures of both the giant ape and his latest director.
Table 19 is never boring, and it has a handful of laugh out loud moments compelled by its talented ensemble, but it really just doesn't amount to much.

While there is certainly a flashiness to The Great Wall -- particularly expressed through a series of large-scale action sequences -- the most accurate adjective available to describe the blockbuster is dull.
Bleeding a special cinematic language while being brilliantly unique, it's put together unlike anything you've seen before
A near-perfect sequel... a movie that wonderfully accentuates everything that is excellent about its predecessor.
It's absolutely worth hunting down for any passionate cinephile.
Coming together with a pace that is deliberate but never sluggish, Moonlight is a beautifully human cinematic experience, and something to behold.
By the time Passengers hits its underwhelming finale, you almost wish that it didn't start out so strong, just because it's basically all a set up for disappointment.

If the franchise can continually pull off blockbusters with the same level of creative energy and the proper amount of reverence as Rogue One does, there's every reason to expect greatness for years to come.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What Whedon and Marvel have created here is not just extraordinary, but one of the most entertaining and satisfying comic book movies yet.
Allied proves that Zemeckis can still tell great, small-scaled stories, crafting a tight, compelling period drama driven by a pair of fantastic lead performances.
Impressive, unique, and inspiring.
A wonderful and culturally-inspired fairy tale that captivates and thrills while shining the spotlight on a mythos rarely explored by Hollywood.
With absolutely no kind of pacing or structure, the movie just ambles narratively from one scene to the next, never putting together a full story let alone any kind of arcs or character development.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Founder is a character study about the expansion of the McDonald's fast food chain, but operates as a hero's journey moving in reverse.

There are certainly shades of Iron Man and Thor, but what the film brings to the table to balance out its familiar elements is some of the most bombastic, exciting and beautiful action sequences we've seen in modern blockbusters.
Sofia Coppola successfully uses this story to carve out some fantastic character dynamics and atmosphere - while handling a narrative that never quite delivers enough twists and turns.
It's visually stunning, beautifully prescient in its humanist themes, and while its reach doesn't match its grasp in some respects, you're still left respecting the hell out of the reach alone.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A story of a dreamer that inspires you to dream; art that celebrates the capabilities of passion; and a spectacularly-presented, thrilling adventure.
With the help of an incredible number of talented artists and performers, it's a movie that plays on the best of the writer/directors sensibilities, while accessing entirely brand new areas of it.
A work that is utterly toothless and boring, full of nothing but cheap jump scares timed out around a trope-filled plot that audiences have seen hundreds of times in bad modern genre films.
It's quirky but never cloying; creative but never over-the-top; and funny without sacrificing drama.
12 Strong knows it has an interesting story to tell with a unique perspective, and it tells it well with a collection of talented actors and some legitimately gripping action.
Proud Mary is a film that wasn't screened in advance for critics, and it doesn't take long for you to fully understand why.
You will find yourself kind of hating yourself for chuckling, but it is part of the experience and conversation.
Propped up by strong material, every member of the Star Wars: The Last Jedi cast delivers performances worthy of the iconic franchise, but deserving special mention is Mark Hamill.
Even if you've never heard of The Room, what James Franco has to offer here a fantastic, hilarious true Hollywood story that is as phenomenal as its subject matter is awful.
Walking out of the theater you can't help but think, "Why wasn't that better?"
An immensely important time period, but [one that] also succeeds in feeling tremendously relevant.
It has a significant story to tell -- shining a light on the importance of supporting veterans and the lack of what's available -- and tells it with some powerful imagery and fantastic performances.
The best of the Thor features and impressively one of the better MCU offerings.
The movie is at its best when it's keeping things simple, specifically with the game of cat and mouse that plays out between Pierce Brosnan and Jackie Chan.
The Mountain Between Us almost has a hypnotizing quality to it, with so many impressive parts operating within a machine that doesn't really doesn't function properly.
A breathtaking, mind-bending cinematic experience.
At the end of the day, it has one hell of a story to tell, and tells it in a visually arresting way, and sometimes that's enough for a proper cinematic experience.
It's not only exciting to see a movie that can elicit such an impressive visceral reaction, but also create a rich, cinematic world that somehow manages to be both terrifying and inviting.
As incisive and gonzo as the material is, you're also left wishing that it featured bolder, more stylistic decisions in its direction and aesthetic.
Clocking in at only 107 minutes long, Dunkirk is tightly paced, and end-to-end it is furnished with stunning sequences that leave you holding your breath.
Stephen Chbosky's movie delivers a fantastic wallop paired with a necessary and well-delivered message about bravery in the face of fear, and the vitality of acceptance.
One of the biggest cinematic surprises of the year.
With a playful sense of tone, amazing performances, and a sharp bite, Get Out resonates with you long after you've left the theater.
A big part of the enjoyment stems from Emily Blunt's presence, as the actress gives a magnificent performance in The Girl On The Train that arguably ranks as the best of her career to date.
A War never shies away from the true horror of its central subject matter, and succeeds in feeling visceral and emotionally powerful.
Deadpool is a blissfully unique and hilarious action-packed blockbuster that stands as one of the best big-screen superhero origin stories that we've had the pleasure of seeing.
While it's not as narratively strong as most of the Coens' other great works, there's a good chance we'll be calling it one of the funniest movies of 2016.
A better fit for the Jane Austen crowd than those going in expecting tons of enthusiastic bloodletting and badass zombie action.
A vividly entertaining adventure story with beautiful animation and a solid way to continue the arc of the titular protagonist.
Beautiful, deep, cerebral and poetic.
A return to Tarantino's small-scaled, dialogue-heavy, non-linear storytelling, bloody, shocking origins. Quite simply, it's one of his best films.
A demonstration that when you get enough funny people together, it often results in a good amount of laughs.
Unquestionably the best Star Wars movie we've seen in 30 years, and an undeniably entertaining ride - but one certainly not without a collection of narrative flaws.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It tackles complex subject matters with a proportionately complex narrative structure, but with creativity and smart sensibilities that come together as an equally thought-provoking and amusing film.
While the narrative on the whole is ultimately very straightforward and uncomplicated, the weight is provided by some tremendous performances, incredible style, and a magnificent score.
Serves as a solid vehicle for Tom Hardy, and while it's never boring, it also doesn't carry a great deal of weight.

The Accountant doesn't really amount to much, mostly sticking to boilerplate, standard action setups as some really great actors regularly pop up on the screen... but it does have something legitimately special in its hero.
A compelling drama anchored by a great lead performance
Jay Roach's film does its job telling Trumbo's important story - just not in an overly fascinating or creative way.
A really wonderful continuation of the original comic strip's great legacy that should earn it an entire new generation of fans, and is guaranteed to make you smile.
A run-of-the-mill zombie movie that the filmmakers hope is buoyed by ridiculously sophomoric humor - but even that doesn't really work.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging and well-made movie about a very important and controversial time.
Yet another boring, creativity-lacking sequel.
It's hard to clinically define this as a "good" movie, but its merits as a fine and enjoyable one are certainly arguable.
A shallow, lifeless semi-musical propped up by YouTube videos from fans who will surely be mortified to see what has been done with their favorite '80s pop icon.
It's not to be taken too seriously, but Eddie The Eagle definitely succeeds as a silly, entertaining underdog story.
It's pretty clear that the filmmaking team has seen Michael Mann's Heat at least a few times - but that's only intended as a compliment.
A character-driven comedy that's as dramatically satisfying as it is hilariously funny, all while fully capturing the spirit of the season
A movie that's equal parts ridiculous, adorable, and laugh-out-loud funny.
The word "adequate" is an accurate one in describing the opening two chapters of The Divergent Series, but Allegiant is the first to really be legitimately bad.
A movie that perfectly understands its strengths and capitalizes on them, crafting a fun story for a fun ensemble.
There are shockingly few scenes that manage to add to the story in a meaningful way, and it results in more drag than a plane taking off with its flaps up.
Yoga Hosers feels underwritten and not thoughtfully made -- the opposite of the trademarks in Kevin Smith's earlier work.
A much different film than what we've seen from Todd Phillips in the past -- but it's also the best movie he's made so far, and a great late summer surprise.
Suicide Squad isn't exactly the movie that audiences are hoping for, and not the bounce-back that the series needed after Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice.

This is the first one that just wears its tropes on its sleeve -- making it feel uninspired and artificial (two adjectives that particularly sting when you consider that this is the character's big screen return after a nine year hiatus).

While Lin's success with big battles and explosions are hardly a surprise given his background in the Fast & Furious franchise, that in no way undercuts how jaw-dropping and thrilling Star Trek Beyond's biggest set pieces are.
No, Paul Feig's Ghostbusters is not as good as Ivan Reitman's 1984 hit. But it is still a fun blockbuster worthy of curiosity and delivering a great number of laughs.
It's off-beat in all the best ways, has fantastic actors all delivering fantastic performances, and is a uproarious adventure with endless heart.
David Lowery has crafted a beautiful, earnest family film with wonderful emotion and pathos that should see it continually watched for years.
Between the fantastic talent of and chemistry between Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga, and the vision of James Wan, The Conjuring 2 demonstrates incredible potential for the emerging franchise.
A less-than-mediocre follow-up with a small handful of interesting ideas.
[It] isn't as good as its predecessor, but it's a fun comedy made by smart, talented people, and it's certainly a lot better than you would expect.
The detective genre has persisted because it has everything you could want from a film - intrigue, action, suspense, romance, adventure and humanity - and Black's latest delivers all of that.
A taut thriller that you'll find yourself vaguely remembering eight years from now as being "pretty good."
Bringing together tremendous character dynamics; bold structure; an emotional narrative; and spell-binding, fun action sequences, it's everything a blockbuster should be.
Most certainly not a movie for everyone, but it's a film that's blessed with the clear knowledge of exactly who it's for and delivers specifically for that crowd.
If this kind of pitch black humor has a way of tickling your funny bone, however, then you should prepare to see one of the most hysterical films of your life.
On a scale of Cars 2 to Toy Story 3, Finding Dory is about on par with Monsters University - delivering more of characters that audiences love, while not quite reaching the level of its predecessor.
Like [Dazed and Confused], the movie is a celebration of the fun and freedom of youth, and it's simply in capturing this spirit that makes it succeed.

Best of Enemies is a spellbinding story, a poignant tale of foibles among greatness, and a vivid portrait of events that were like the year they occurred -- a stark line between what was, and what thereafter would be.
Adventureland is ultimately an interesting but flawed mixture of Mottolla's early indie sensibility (The Daytrippers) with some of the more mainstream teen comedy elements of Superbad.

While it's not quite a home run, there's a lot to enjoy about Tucker & Dale vs. Evil. It's got its heart in the right place, and hey, it's just nice to root for the hillbillies for once in this scenario!
After too long an absence in the spotlight, this movie is a vivid reminder of how much we all could use some Muppets in our lives.

Both fans of the books and those brand new to the story of Katniss Everdeen will find The Hunger Games compelling. With the first film proving the series is in good hands, I'm excited to see the next chapters play out onscreen.
The Cabin in the Woods is continually smart, funny and surprising, reflecting horror films back at themselves in new and exciting ways.
So much of Men in Black III just kind of sits there.
Cho and Penn continue to be a likable pair who work well off each other and it's fun to spend time with them, even in the movie's off moments.
This is a sweet film about an unusual but notable part of "Hollywood," for a group of people who have, for the most part, barely been to Los Angeles.
It took nearly a half-century to make it happen onscreen, but The Avengers was worth the wait, pairing together the perfect cast and perfect writer/director.
The story worked in 1984 and it works now.
It's a hit or miss comedy where the misses win, percentage-wise.
Consistently funny and outrageous, with a large, appealing cast whose apparent good time making the film is infectious.

Final Destination 5 is a much-improved installment for the series on the heels of the terrible fourth film, The Final Destination, and an example of getting what you pay for in a suitably satisfying manner.
Utterly lifeless and dull and quite simply hard to sit through.
It's Craven's best film since Scream 2, back in 1997, as the veteran horror director seems to flourish (Scream 3 aside) when telling a story of this sort and balancing the comedy and horror elements.

This is a Harry Potter film that functions as a dark, emotional character study more than a fun adventure, which will be disconcerting for some. But if you love these characters, as many of us do, you'll find a lot to admire.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As a fan of the series, it was impossible not to be bothered by how little time was spent with either Jigsaw or Gordon, the characters that mean the most to the series at this point.
It's all about the execution, and among plenty of dead on arrival teen films, Nick and Norah is legitimately funny, sweet and charming.
While it's visually appealing, the new Elm Street fails to sustain momentum or create much genuine tension.
Beyond the physical resemblance the filmmakers managed to give her, Mol gives a truly breakout performance here.
Forced and undercooked from start to finish.
A silly, awkward, but sometimes very funny movie.
The film soon proves to be not only unfunny, but something worse: boring.
Flightplan grows more and more ponderous and frustrating as the reasons behind Kyle's predicament are revealed to be increasingly outlandish.
The film feels like the victim of too many rewrites and edits, with lots of plotlines that go nowhere or feel oddly unfulfilled.
An admirably flawed film.
It never gels and one of the biggest problems is the lack of a consistent tone.
Maybe it's not one of his very best haunted house stories, but it's del Toro, so it's still entertaining.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Nickelodeon goes outside their comfort zone with Fun Size, but the film is very hit or miss, with an inconsistent tone.
North Country centers on Theron's work, and she is truly wonderful start to finish.
Dark Skies falters when it moves beyond that family unit.

Kumail Nanjiani and Emily V. Gordon have told their own story in a funny, highly engaging way that doesn't feel precious or sanitized, but instead is relatable and engrossing from start to finish. And you'll laugh a hell of a lot.
The Cars series finally finds its inner Pixar in its third, much more thoughtful installment.

Powered by Bill Condon's direction and terrific performances from a game cast, it's a lovely film that includes the elements fans of the animated classic would hope to see, while also introducing some new aspects.
Yes, it's a cheesy slasher film, but you know that going in, and this is a well-done example of the genre.
Rogue One is a movie crammed with fan service, but when fan service is done this well, there's little to complain about and much to adore.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film delivers the strong humor, well executed action, memorable music and lovable characters Disney has perfected in a delightful and lovely manner.
A few fun 3D-aided jump-scares aside, Texas Chainsaw 3D is a generic and laughable attempt to follow the original.
What really ends up making Doctor Strange an entertaining film are the actors and the visuals.

The things about Pee-wee Herman that made him funny and endearing... 30 years ago still work today and Paul Reubens and his collaborators have managed to create a clever and creative batch of characters and set pieces for him.
Zootopia is a wonderful example of how Disney, at its best, can mix its past and present together in a very cool, compelling way.

If you hate musicals and hate Grease, Grease Live! sure wasn't going to change your mind all of the sudden. But for the multi-generational fanbase who admire this show, there was plenty to love about Grease Live!
Hanks does a strong job with his documentary debut here, giving All Things Must Pass a lot of energy and an endearing quality. It helps that the interview subjects are so engaging and likable.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: No, it doesn't quite equal that first movie, but it's funny throughout, filled with many commendably outrageous moments.

The personalities involved and the stories they tell are worthwhile and offer some great insight into just what a struggle it can be when so many people try to work together to pull off a film of this scope.
movie_title: The Death of Superman Lives: What Happened? (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Tomorrowland has its flaws, yet it's also a compelling movie, with a lot of cool ideas.
It's like an elaborate, expensive cosplay with big explosions and set pieces and enough of a winking sense of humor to let you know everyone is there to have a good time.
Subverting audience expectations of an over the top "teenage girl killer" movie with a character study could have been great, but the character study in question feels paper thin.
I was liking Monsters University the whole way through, but it gets some extra points for its third act.
The story of Carrie innately works, so it's not that this movie needed to change what happens - it just feels too dependent on telling it in the exact way De Palma did.
Catching Fire is another strong installment in this confident series.
It's certainly more entertaining than the dour, dull Terminator Salvation and I found myself at least having fun with Genisys much of the time.
The Paranormal series has perfected the art of the sudden, shocking thing happening during a seemingly quiet moment, which continues here.
The resulting film, Noah, has its flaws but ultimately is a fascinating achievement -- a continually ambitious undertaking that swings for the fences and then some.

Despite the strange revamp of the Turtles into huge, superpowered behemoths who seem ready to throw down with Colossus or the Thing, the film does a nice job of capturing their brotherly in-fighting, camaraderie and rapport.
Dumb and Dumber To sits in the "enjoyable retread of the first film" category.
This is a really entertaining film overall, doing justice to Stephen Sondheim's fun, skewed look at the world of fairy tales.
The film commits fully to its tone and is grounded by great work by both Breslin and, yes, Schwarzenegger.
A fun, joyful film that once more reminds us why the Muppets are so wonderful.
Love & Sex is capable of making even the most cynical Gen-Xer watch with an involuntary smile.
Blaustein paints a complex picture of professional wrestling and shrewdly transforms the ridiculous into the sublime.
Sadly, Kirk Douglas' real-life stroke is the most compelling ingredient in Miramax's new cobbled-together caper flick.
Definitely wasn't worth the drive.
In short bursts of late-night TV, ATHF is cramp-inducingly funny. Stretched over 87 minutes, it's too much to bear. Fast food cures the munchies but makes for a terrible diet.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, after almost two hours the gloom becomes monotonous and the one-dimensional characters wear out their welcome.
It's precisely by challenging our need for good and bad stereotypes that makes this film ultimately captivating and, with the twists in the end, highly rewarding.
For reactionary propaganda, the movie admittedly is fun, in a modest way.

It's no surprise that Nick Broomfield finds little use for the moments of unabashed triumphalism in Houston's life, as he's doggedly fixated on the humiliating swan dive.
The film is both the last great gasp of '60s hippie ethos and the first masterpiece of what would become an increasingly technocratic '80s movie-house takeover.
movie_title: Close Encounters Of The Third Kind: 40th Anniversary Release (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It cashes in on trendy retroism--the remedial, brash distant second cousin to nostalgia--instead of utilizing the perspective of, to borrow from Joni Mitchell, seeing clowns from both sides now.
Far from seeming like a strategic element created to define Lady Gaga's reinvention, the documentary instead feels like a natural outgrowth of it.
Marshall arguably intends for societal 20/20 hindsight to provide the bulk of perspective throughout.
Thor: Ragnarok is the flamboyantly roller-disco entry in an already uncomplicatedly cartoonish side franchise.
Since "humbug" is already spoken for by Ebenezer Scrooge, "opportunistic" would be the most apt word for The Man Who Invented Christmas.
Any potential subtext of Munro Leaf's children's book has been bleached out in the marketplace-oriented Ferdinand.

The film, which finished shooting more than two years ago before spending endless months without a release date, is both meandering and bloated, suggesting the Frankensteinian result of brutal test screenings.
The only wish that ends up satisfyingly granted is, in Wish Upon's final and utterly predictable tableau, the audience's.
It's a pity that no one else involved in the making of the film had Dwayne Johnson's sly intuition.
It punks its impressionable audience into believing a lie, then punishes them for their foolishness.
The film fails to anchor its CGI or events with emotional heft.
The film turns its back on all but the most fleeting brand of comic anarchy.
The script doesn't revel in Amy's quite harmless flaws, or at least examine them in the spirit of benevolence.
To hose down the white elephant in the room right off the bat, yes, Paper Towns falls into place as a coming-of-age spin on the Manic Pixie Dream Girl archetype.
Father doesn't just know best, he's the only one whose knowledge or lack thereof means anything at all.
It adds more grist for the mill to the notion that studios don't hit the big red "reboot" button in any other state than a panic.
When the (non-spoiler alert) trademark Shyamalan twist finally arrives, it doesn't synthesize anything other than the director's devotion to his signature gimmick.
It feels less like an cautionary adventure movie or the classy Hollywood equivalent of a Reader's Digest "Drama in Real Life" and much more like a disaster epic.
Nancy Meyers is unquestionably committed to her auteurist signature of giving her female protagonists their cake and letting them eat it too.
It risks offense by putting a typically Adam Sandler-ian twist on a tired familial trope, though such risks can often be the only thing enlivening forced franchise installments like this one.
Joe Wright's film could fuel an entire series of incredulous episodes of the How Did This Get Made? podcast.
It's the screenwriting equivalent of Ryan Adams sucking the pop vitality out of Taylor Swift's deliriously produced tunes.
It only serves to validate George Clooney's devotion to showmanship as Hollywood's current reigning poster boy for blue-state morality.
The flick is an artless, puerile shadow of the likes of Edgar Wright and Simon Pegg's Cornetto trilogy.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Imagine a Christmas tree covered not only in tinsel and lights and silver bulbs, but also snow globes and perfume samples and beef jerky and vials of virgin tears.
Billy Ray unfurls the parallel time structure with the same flat, procedural monotony applied by Juan José Campanella to the original film.
In the film, Alvin and the Chipmunks proudly align themselves not with Dr. Demento, but with Kidz Bop.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Though Will Ferrell has made a career out of his own debasement, the film quickly becomes too cruel to generate laughter for anyone who would empathize with him.
Like any serving of junk food, it seems engineered to give you that initial rush of satisfaction, but leaves you in a dead zone where the only thing you want is more of the same.
The sense that children's attitudes toward rampant militarization are being gradually normalized is the film's objectionable given.
Most Nicholas Sparks adaptations say, in cinematic terms, nothing so complicated as "roses are red." This one just points to a garden and shrugs.
If the accepted wisdom is that chronically single people don't know what they want, the film will stay alone for life.
It's an episode of Without a Trace: Jerusalem presented with all the panache of a Trinity Broadcasting Network TV special.
As far as shameless excuses to rehash crowd-pleasing gags from the first film go, it doesn't particularly go about its duties cynically.
It clips its own wings and tames the force of nature at its center, short circuiting its potential as a rude-tempered star vehicle.
A pop sonata of stand-up comedy routines layered with, if not vitality, then at least honest energy.
Key and Peele aren't mining territory they haven't already explored at length on their Comedy Central sketch show, nor do they do a whole lot to elaborate on it.
The Angry Birds Movie is a lot of things, but none of them true to the app's appeal.
It hits its Red State beats so hard that its target audience likely won't notice they're being not only condescended to, but insulted outright.
Whitney Houston's death is just about the only thing that gives the film real, albeit mostly unintentional, life.
There's little doubt where Cormac McCarthy-bashing Sparks's allegiances lie. The Longest Ride is truly no country for old ambiguity.

Dark Knight channeled the nervous energy of a larger cultural movement. Rises swaggers as though it is the larger movement. Whether or not that's a good thing depends on how highly you rank being a Batman fan among your life goals.
The tension doesn't so much revolve around the antihero's job, redemption, or ultimate fate but rather the disconnect between its mundane milieu and the grandiose flourishes they're meant to convey.
Both the crypto-zombies of Nightmare City and the film itself are fast-paced sons of bitches without so much as a whisper of a thought inside their heads.
movie_title: Incubo sulla città contaminata (Nightmare City) (Invasion by the Atomic Zombies) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't ever end up communicating anything other than its own capacity for sensitive understatement.
Sour and pointless.
movie_title: Lo Squartatore di New York (The New York Ripper) (1982)

movie_review_blurb: The menu buttons are shaped like sombreros. I trust I needn't say more.

Biller's film is to the films of Radley Metzger and Russ Meyer what Todd Haynes's Far From Heaven was to Douglas Sirk, only perhaps a little bit cannier and a lot less dryly academic about its postmodern tweaks.
A loose remake of Female Trouble with Polyester's subversively accessible polish, Serial Mom is the strongest film of the post-midnight-movie chapter of John Waters's career.
When it sticks to kinetically portraying the sheer oddness of the tornadic phenomenon, Twister is a breeze. When it tries to recreate Hawks, it falls gracelessly from the green sky.
Another case study delving into the hubris and insult of trying too hard to feel someone else's pain.

Apatow's talent for accurately portraying his generation at their most self-absorbed doesn't quite go as far at justifying the script's patchy, haphazard conflicts at it does toward explaining the film's bloated running time.
In the theater, whenever Mike, Crow or Tom Servo flub a punchline or resort to a fart joke, you almost want to lean forward and shush them.

The reality is that this is the film that comes closest to reflecting the racism, sexism and jingoism that fuelled most of the serials that originally sparked Spielberg and George Lucas's impressionable young imaginations.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984)

movie_review_blurb: Chipmunk Adventure is worth one toked-out viewing for Dody Goodman's gratingly senile Miss Miller and her description of the trio's daily breakfast menu.
Miraculously avoids leaden 'significance' in favor of a sagacious lived-in-ness.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I have to admit this is probably the smartest entry in the series.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: He had my heart racing like a squirrel. He had my body soaring into the stratosphere like a bird. He had me slippery and firm like a fresh young perch.
While the movie is every bit as garish and overly shellacked as the other bomb musicals of its era, at least this one looks like irresponsible amounts of money were thrown around.
A penetrating contemplation of the American industrial-military complex's obstreperous legacy.

Fastidiously attuned to the denial of the comforting release of either eroticism or expulsion, Pasolini's boudoirs of perversion lack De Sade's scarlet hedonism. Quite the opposite, his boners reveal only the presence of spiritual rigor mortis.
movie_title: Salò o le 120 giornate di Sodoma (Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild aims for a self-knowingness that could conceivably be mislabeled as camp by any one of its *****-brained lead characters.
movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Being neither Mexican nor Jewish, I imagine I'm the perfect audience for the chaotically cross-cultural ethnography farce of My Mexican Shivah.
movie_title: Morirse esta en Hebreo (My Mexican Shivah) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I'm sure Child's Play was far from the only film of its era sold as one of the great scareshows of all time.
A haunting examination of another photographer's work.
movie_title: Le Souvenir d'un avenir (Remembrance of Things to Come) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The catch is that the letters are addressing a dead man.
What do all these subtle modifications to the otherwise similar template suggest?

An upstart thriller about a young man's initiation into politics and life, Choose Connor is not coincidentally getting a theatrical release during an election that will likely mark an old man's exit from both politics and life.
William Klein's films may be more arrogant than anything by Jean-Luc Godard. Americans...always trying to outdo everyone.

Stylistically, Arthur Penn's crime epic doesn't do anything that hadn't already been seen in any number of runty, skuzzy teen epics, all of which firmly established the paragons of good (i.e. "The Law") as being the new antagonists.
Charles Bronson gets screwed over in Violent City. In fact, he gets screwed over so many times that the film loses track of its internal timeline.

Cruella De Vil is so much a tour de force that she single-handedly snatches the movie away from any retroactive comparisons to post-classical Disney features whose sloppiness is the is their only saving grace.
The film tries a little too fastidiously to piece together a life its owner tried quite brazenly to shatter.
movie_title: Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Documentary director Victor Magnatti is more comfortable with loud and proud, and perhaps a tad suspicious of insinuation and circumspection.
In practice it's a little more Stripped to Your Bra and Panties, You Run and Squeal and Maybe Get Gently Choked to Death As Though Your Trachea Were Made of Butter.
movie_title: The Young, the Evil and the Savage (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Parenthood is a middlebrow masterpiece. Not a masterpiece of middlebrow but a middlebrow masterpiece, with the latter word being the subject, not the modifier.
Just as Mac and Me eventually devolved into a feature-length commercial for McDonald's, Harry and the Hendersons eventually emerges as a vegetarian screed.
Violette doesn't so much rejuvenate the "sex = death" equation that had been in place since Louise Brooks opened Pandora's Box as it does struggle to remember why women want sex in the first place.
If the film has endured it's because of a few aspects particular to Fuller's career, which began not in film but in yellow journalism and pulp writing.
Arrogantly conceived, pretentiously executed, and petulantly protracted.
Bends over backwards to celebrate the perception that the box office success of Fame and Flashdance heralded the rebirth of the form.
RoboCop set the tone for much of Dutch auteur import Paul Verhoeven's career in America.
It's not Justine's yielding vaginal lips that are most in danger of inviting immorality but her unyielding air of self-denial.
Why Cruising? Why now? And why does it feel like how you answer those questions will determine which side pocket you keep your handkerchief in?
The legacy of Chris Marker weeps when the future of essay filmmaking looks like a feature-length commercial for Ambien.

The film, a purported examination of male sexuality, was directed and written by women, and thus all we get is two super-sensitive men stroking each others' emotional baggage instead of licking each others' *****.
The Devil may wear Prada, but the rest of the fashion world wears pink, at least according to Stanley Donen's endearingly naive Funny Face.
The literally last-minute stab at domestic foreplay is simply unbelievable, but Baloo's lip-licking post-mortem ("I still think he'd a made one swell bear") is what sticks.
Lagerfeld Confidential lives up to its title by keeping its central topic top secret.
After a quarter-century, Poltergeist remains one of the most popular movies whose reputation rests almost exclusively on behind-the-scenes diversions.
Directed by Lewis Teague with less cinematographic flair than even the TV miniseries for 'Salem's Lot, Cujo unfortunately demonstrates the difficulty in adapting King's shorter works.
Lewis Teague is only too willing to hand over the entire project to Sayles's hunger for allegorical subplots.
It's the experience more so than the actual content of The Shining that radiates cold, anti-humanly indifferent terror.
Rob Reiner's films have always aimed for a heartwarming effect and more frequently resulted in heartworm.

Cecilia isn't that far removed from the world of the nighttime soap.

The Aristocats is one of the slightest of director Wolfgang Reitherman's contributions to the Disney animated feature canon, which is to say it's still among the studio's least suffocatingly ornate and ideologically risible films.
It's one of Pierrot's unique charms that Godard doesn't regard Ferdinand and Marianne's situation with emphatic mockery or inordinate reverence.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: This minor cult classic has its fans, to be sure, but it never really pays off.
movie_title: Non si deve profanare il sonno dei morti (Let Sleeping Corpses Lie) (Don't Open the Window) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Tim Burton's imagination jumped into the saddle and held onto the bridle with Beetlejuice.

movie_title: Who Does She Think She Is? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Simultaneously an act of revisionism as well as a parody of then-revitalizing neo-noir.
For a movie with this many ideological loose ends, Otto comes up with a convincingly sweet resolution.
movie_title: Otto; or Up with Dead People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Birth of a Nation itself is a set of cinematic training wheels.
As insistently wry as it is haunting.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's tongue-in-cheek (and pre-subprime) satire of surging capitalist hubris is scarcely mitigated by the necessary fairy-tale ending.
Sure, Tati's script may have been small, but there's such depth of content in each setup.
Kagemusha, much like the similarly overblown but handsomely mounted Lawrence of Arabia, is an epic with a cipher in its point position.

A good dint lower than its reputation, more so if you look at it not as one of the seminal 1970s films but instead as the first chapter from the finest filmmaking career spent examining the American mystique.
It is Snow White's afterbirth that merits both canonization and destruction.
movie_title: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)

movie_review_blurb: Given just how much material Kenny Ortega and his editors plowed through to whittle together a two-hour scrapbook and they still could only just barely come up with the presentable material here isn't exactly a vindication.
Say "Merchant-Ivory" to most cinephiles and watch their eyelids sag.
The gift of time and perspective has added a few kinks to what seems a mostly pedestrian experience.
movie_title: Word Is Out: Stories of Some of Our Lives (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Stonewall Uprising deploys familiar PSA-cum-hate-crimes like the infamous "Boys Beware" with very little restraint in order to truly establish Stonewall's prehistory as a No M2M's Land.

movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Kilmi and Aarma's look back is both affectionate and skeptical.
movie_title: Disco and Atomic War (Disko ja tuumasoda) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hallows: Part 1 isn't a film at all. It's a placeholder. And its makers are making fans pay for the privilege of remaining caught up.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Is it too much to ask for one wig to get snatched?
The Leopard is more than a tad too pleased by its own spots, but in this case the source material and its director's intentions were almost accidentally an appropriate match.
David Sigal's documentary may not quite manage to canonize the diner, at least not to flyover country, but it sure makes it sound like a good meal and a great time.
movie_title: Florent: Queen Of The Meat Market (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Electronica is the next progression, and Jacqueline Caux caps her otherwise rarified musical program with a rave anthem from Plastikman to drive the point home.
movie_title: The Colors of the Prism, The Mechanics of Time (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Dimly plays out like a waking daymare Alexander Payne thought up while sitting disinterestedly through last fall's disinteresting Waiting for Superman.

Heteros get their Crazy, Stupid, Love. this weekend, and I guess gay New Yorkers, fresh off their immensely satisfying we-have-arrived nuptials, get their own Crazy, Stupid, Tragedy. as counterprogramming.
Limelight, like the club it's named after, doesn't do much to break the mold of sex-drugs-and-star****ers sameness afflicting this particular subgenre.
The longer you spend inside Weekend, the more its fictions seem apparent.
The directive given to the filmmakers behind The Amazing Spider-Man was undoubtedly: strut that teen angst.
Gah, bare flesh pecs on screen drool cup need quick!!
In space, everyone can hear you try too hard.
Aims to recapture the original's seamless pastiche (it's an imitation of an imitation) and fails. But it has an easily digestible, junky sense of humor about it.
A triune plot that Ferrara digs into with sleeves fully rolled up.
The recurring attitude throughout most interpretations of Marienbad is that of sheer interpretation fatigue.
movie_title: L'année dernière à Marienbad (Last Year at Marienbad) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Like Rear Window to Alfred Hitchcock, like Nashville to Robert Altman, like Playtime to Jacques Tati, Lee's Do the Right Thing is an undiluted representation of its creator's artistic command.
It's summer movie smack, and it leaves you hungry only for more of the same.

Swedish cinema titan Ingmar Bergman's mopey/earthy 1957 breakthrough The Seventh Seal may have done more than any other film to popularize and demonize the notion of world cinema as the boutique of the cultural intelligentsia.
Dr. Strangelove's status as the movie that confirmed both Stanley Kubrick's reputation and the arrival of beat-sick irreverence can no longer be retracted.
movie_title: Dr. Strangelove Or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964)

movie_review_blurb: Neither Meryl Streep's as-yet-unpolished performance nor the entire construction of this particular production of Bertolt Brecht's celebrated play are done much favor by this doc's unedifying attempt to shoot the moon.
A close-up but still, one senses, heavily idealized documentary portrait.
What people don't quite give Sirk credit for nowadays in their rush to justify his intellectual credentials is the fact that if he didn't necessarily believe in the cheesecake he served up.
With all the subtlety of Battleship Potemkin, a queue full of sour-faced old school nannies is shown blowing away into thin air to make way for the embodiment of modern female assertiveness.
If anything, The Stewardesses proves that the 1960s were hardly a heyday for free love on both sides of the gender divide.
I guess I can cut the Mouse House a little slack when it comes to paint-by-numbers mediocrities like Oliver & Company.
Ground Zero for the cult of Sellers.
The one thing the film got right was the crushed effect the media's growing omnipresence has had on human existence.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)

movie_review_blurb: It ain't only the DeLorean that's out of gas.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part III (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Splendor in the Grass is a prestigious, top-of-the-line, sensitively-handled melodramatic literalization of the axiom "If you touch yourself too much, you'll go crazy."
Not since Larry David's Sour Grapes has a movie kicked off by so thoroughly painting its protagonists as deeply unlikable souls.
Nope, no perverted subtext here.
Probably the most carefully-scripted blockbuster in Hollywood history.
And what of New York's disco-era gays? They're written out of the story here just as decisively as they were written out of Levenson's version of utopia.
Do you have to be a Minnesotan to really get Fargo?

Dodes'ka-den's forgotten souls enact their tribulations only in brief, impressionistic strokes, as apt to lapse into candy-coated reverie as they are to stare down the demons of fiscal and moral poverty.
Russo and Streiner use their sex comedy to espouse the retrograde notion that the only fulfilling sexual position is one-man-one-woman missionary.
One has to marvel at just how perfectly Hughes nails his frustratingly entitled mise-en-scène, which he unquestionably does in the film's mesmerizing detour inside an art museum.

A masterpiece among masterpieces, the two-part, three-hour A Grin Without a Cat is Chris Marker's most ambitious, clear-headed string of cinematic clauses and ideological couplets, and also his most impenetrable.
movie_title: Le Fond de l'air est rouge (A Grin Without a Cat) (The Base of the Air Is Red) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: To paraphrase a crack from Pauline Kael: light the incense, perverts.
movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Saturday Night Fever's heart is actually in the right place. It's ears, though? That's another story.
It's probably a stretch to surmise that, just as the first film's subtext dealt with health fears, the sequel mines its dread from the horror of malpractice.
The 400 Blows, one of the initiating sparks of the French New Wave, ultimately boils down to the film's trendsetting coda, perhaps the most exclamatory question mark in movies.

Barker's vision cribs equally from the mythos of vampires and zombies, but Hellraiser's overriding ridiculousness (and nagging budgetary shortcomings) can't disguise the fact that the movie is at least unwittingly a product of the AIDS crisis.
Serves as a fairly surface-oriented hagiography of a self-conscious rock star photographer.
Now seems much less like Salt of the Earth-as-a-potboiler and a lot more like the spiritual godfather to every testosterone-fuelled thrill ride since.

It can be easy to dismiss the hardships of rent-controlled bohemians, but as seen from the inside, it's clear that something much bigger was at stake: the very heart of a city that prides itself on art, but habitually privileges the bottom line.

Trade out Las Vegas for Bangkok, a tiger for a monkey, a lactating hooker for a trannie stripper, a missing tooth for a face tattoo, and you've got Todd Phillips's rote, dispiriting replica of his own surprise smash hit.
Veteran character actor Dermot Mulroney unleashes his inner cornball for this directorial debut, a softly lit, wind-chimes-scored diversion for the Celestial Seasonings set.
This boppy biopic pushes a wealth of outrageous incidents while never making anything resembling a point.
A nonstop movie that's nonetheless more captivatingly caffeinated than compelling...

Even with the rich, inherently cinematic texture of the urban setting and two excellent native outer-borough actors in Morales and Reyes, Gun Hill Road falters thanks to its paint-by-numbers storytelling.
It's a thriller, it's a strip-club soap opera, it's an inner-child reclamation inspirational -- it's really unpleasant to look at.
Voices are raised, guns are cocked, and actors slice ham by the pound...
Resurrect Dead works splendidly as a threadbare urban mystery, teasing out details and complications without withholding too much information.
movie_title: Resurrect Dead: The Mystery of the Toynbee Tiles (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Make Believe eagerly (and predictably) fulfills rather than transcends the expectations of the genre.
The first major motion picture to come out of Congo in decades happens to be one of the best neonoirs from anywhere in recent memory.

A lot of history gets horned into this undeniably inspirational parable, though slick execution and simplistic storytelling make it a lesson suitable only for easily impressed elementary-school students.
Gutierrez clearly has great affection for his characters, but his artless, airless construction gives audiences scant chance to understand why.
Legendary Japanese softcore auteur Kôji Wakamatsu channels Samuel Fuller for a twisted domestic-drama-cum-psychosexual-evisceration of Japan's fascist past.
The real casualties are momentum and narrative cohesion.
Exporting offers an intriguing outsider's document of Russian culture reinventing itself from the outside in; its main export, however, seems to be good old-fashioned Ugly Americanism.
Rather than an argument or exposé, the movie is a condescendingly narrated demonstration of how money makes the movie world go round. (Stop the presses.)
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Goffman's either unwilling or incapable of getting them to move their lips to reveal enough of themselves, or of their artistry, to make the already overly familiar endeavor worth anyone's time.

More info packet than a story, the film is carefully designed for unambiguous impact.
By discreetly dismantling our familiar frame of reference rather than alienatingly flying in the face of it, A Woman Under the Influence is singularly effective in its radical intent.
Strain is evident elsewhere.
Alternating between impressive and pedestrian shot-making, professional and amateurish acting, the film aims for gravitas and entertainment but only occasionally achieves either.
I know that people like this exist, but, in terms of characters on the screen, I'm never shown why they need to.
movie_title: Gabi on the Roof in July (2011)

movie_review_blurb: When an errant ax lands in Alba's thigh, the film goes from inept to kind of brilliantly bad; it's a teachable moment, though lessons learned may vary.
All those shots of heavenly shafts of light eventually climax in unabashed Christian conversion.
Gil's alternative history gets one thing bang-on right: If Butch were to live into his senior days, he'd absolutely have to be played by Shepard.
Thankfully, the kids' complicated impulses resist such packaging, whether they're catcalling head-scarved co-eds outside the local gas station or channeling racial resentments into extra hard hits.
Despite a few moments of surprising insight, Twelve Thirty comes off as more mechanistic than organic; it's composed rather than truly lived.
For once, an American indie's muted modesty at least makes emotional sense, suiting a bittersweet romance that, by nature, has neither a name nor a future.
A ghastly vanity affair for one Whitney Smith, the son of a socialite who, despite minimal credits to his name, feels entitled to make Halston's story his own.
Cheney is welcome to his anxiety, but not to the specious science of societal collapse by street lamp.

movie_review_blurb: An amateurish travelogue that feels like a botched assignment, halfheartedly self-regarding and resentfully remote from the object of our fascination.

Sattel constructs a tone poem via impeccably composed pictures that toe the line between beauty and banality, revelation and tedium.
The latest film to ride Joseph Campbell's The Power of Myth as if it were a nonconsensual pony, A Warrior's Heart tries to fashion a hero's journey out of a Seventeen spread.
The transposition to present day is confusing and counterproductive, dulling the impact of an otherwise fierce, often unbearably immediate production.
Boy meets girl. Boy likes girl. Girl faints and boy jumps out the bathroom window.
Quote not available.
Rebirth never persuasively builds to catharsis, and that's entirely for the best. Forget transcendence: The quintet's return to normal, quotidian lives is the most inspiring development of all.
It's the archival footage that wows here, showing that before the brand took on yuppie cachet, the Eames team made exquisite objects for the masses.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like a Training Day for spy thrillers, The Double provocatively pairs Gere and Grace as a gray-green odd couple, only to unravel as the double-crossed absurdities pile up and the duo start trading bad Russian accents in a private Mexican standoff.

Bunraku aspires to be Kill Bill: Vol 3; it's more like an ornate pitch for a Dick Tracy reboot.
Serves as a rousing testament to the singular blessings of music education, since there's nothing inherent or automatic about kids learning how to groove.
Naturalistic without being ineloquent, heartfelt yet unsentimental, Weekend is the rarest of birds: a movie romance that rings true.
Perhaps Pearl Jam's arc too closely resembles Crowe's own, and he can't see what's so uniquely poignant about dimmed but enduring stars.
Majewski's film is a dazzling master class in visual composition.

Although its subject is never less than captivating, Jonathan Furmanski's film is frustratingly unfocused, a scattershot collection of candid footage and biographical information. Thankfully, Blowfly's world is weird as promised.
Movies often make too much of that truism, but surprisingly committed performances from actors like these can still make it feel like something meaningful.
Reeks of a throwaway joke that should have been left to die; even at a mere 80 minutes, this halfhearted Tinseltown satire still feels padded.
Creates a recognizably adolescent milieu that's also a workable metaphor for the anxieties of the 21st-century press corps.

A scattershot throwback that steals elements from seedy '70s character studies, disreputable '80s vigilante flicks, even street-tough allegories from the '30s, Inside Out also dances to the confidently unhurried beat of its own drum.

That it documents rural poverty in the American West without exploiting or sanctifying its subjects would be cause enough for praise. But this doesn't begin to approach what Alma Har'el pulls off with her hybrid doc knockout Bombay Beach.
Jaglom can craft a scene and stage organic conversations, but if his saps and suckers never wander beyond a hermetic view of the real world, then so what?
Middling, middle-class entertainment aimed at the midpoint between comedy and drama, mass appeal and sophistication, Change of Plans is eager to please and easy to dismiss.
movie_title: Change of Plans (Le Code a Changé) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The most egregious four-quadrant pander-party of the year, Ed Zwick's latest middlebrow atrocity has been so carefully market-tested that it needn't even be seen, just administered directly into the bloody mainstream.
There's inherent drama in watching a person amble up a mountain, but it's an act of bad faith to oversell a stunt.
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Restraint is precisely what makes this quietly harrowing documentary, composed mostly of interviews with former Khmer Rouge henchmen, so uncommonly devastating.
Leon Gast's documentary portrait has a freewheeling charm that perfectly matches its subject.
She's been brave and she's been a pest, but until this adaptation of Beverly Cleary's beloved children's books, pint-size protagonist Ramona Quimby has never been so blatantly market-driven.
The film clandestinely captures marauders in action while embedding itself in the imperiled home of aging farmer Michael Campbell.
Suitably for a film that lacks clear intent or direction, The Contenders just ends, mid-sentence, the point of it all frankly elusive.

Marshall Curry's sleek documentary captures the second-hand thrill of watching tweens hurtle at 70 mph around a blacktop, as it follows three potential superkarters over the course of a single season.
What's unique to Beadie Finzi's debut feature is what it reveals about the financial, physical and emotional costs of talent.
Few things renew one's faith in the moving image more than an unbridled Gina Lollobrigida cavorting in the Adriatic Sea with a flock of sheep.
Director Madeleine Sackler favors an agenda of advocacy over complexity, making The Lottery an effective, if unapologetically one-sided, piece of agitprop.
With tinkling thriller music and dramatic voiceover narration, this modest but engrossing first-person documentary comes on like a true crime caper.
Convention plays like 11 cameras in search of drama.
[An] impassioned, but wearisomely didactic, diaspora drama.
movie_title: Salt of This Sea (Milh Hadha al-Bahr) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: To its credit, the film calls out Christianity's ignominious imperialism and locates a valid historical analogue to the religious extremism of today. Yet good intentions shan't save Amenbar from his own ham-fisted methods.
Ivan Fitzgibbon's film is so steadfastly blithe that one yearns for a flicker of pretension, some small sign that there's a guiding principle or purpose.
Cello-scored pantomimes of resilience and grief can make us feel, but it's not always evident who or what that serves.
Although convincing as athletes, neither Miller belongs on a movie screen; personal parable or not, this feels like a too-familiar trip around the bases.
There's pleasure in watching the conceit unfold, which is sweetened by an unexpectedly poignant payoff.
An expansive take on the world in miniature, Jessica Oreck's documentary debut pursues all angles on a novel subject -- the Japanese obsession with insects -- until it assumes a worldview.
The film isn't pretty -- even the talking-head footage looks a bit hurried -- but neither is the milieu or the era it documents.
Husband-and-wife writer-directors Keiran and Michele Mulroney try to smooth over implausibilities with an intrusive emo soundtrack and "dramedic" feints, but the effort is useless.
A travesty no matter how you look at it, this flaccid art-world farce is best approached as a landmark of dubious ensemble work.
With little in the way of story or spectacle to offer nonbelievers, the film itself just preaches to the choir.

Although based on the real-life tale of nine underage underdogs from Monterrey, Mexico who swept the 1957 Little League World Series, this Cinderella sports story rings false from first pitch to last.
Million Dollar Baby is just the sort of film that we all want but no longer dare expect. It's a fine work of art.
A knowingly subjective portrait that's somewhere between Cubist travelogue and epic poetic reportage.

Stationing the camera at a safe remove and letting scenes run their course, it's the sort of slow-burn romantic drama that asks its actors to bear the emotional brunt of the film -- and its leads deliver.

Ozu's long shots, knee-high camera placement, and collapsed perspective -- as gorgeous and unsettling as a Cézanne -- gather power over the duration, but time itself is the master's most potent weapon.
Both a heartfelt and a genuinely funny skewering of India's convoluted caste-consciousness.
Forget AA; according to the movies, there's no better cure for alcoholism or depression than good ol' precollegiate athletic coaching.
Say what you will about the tediousness, acting ineptitude, and infantilism of Saw 3D, but you can't say it doesn't go all the way.
Quote not available.
It's entertainment designed to resemble a good time without aspiring to provide one.
More of a telethon-ready fund-raiser than a work of dramatic reportage.
After a tantalizingly idiosyncratic beginning... directors Kerthy Fix and Gail O'Hara proceed with a perfectly fine but disappointingly by-the-numbers rock doc.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating look at the complex intersections of art and charity, reality and perception.

The Kids Grow Up is ostensibly about parenthood and memory, but is most revealing about modern marriage -- the elephant that's always in the room, the mystery that can't be solved, a shared past that offers little direction for the future.

Ripped from the headlines and sensationalized for your would-be pleasure, Inhale uses the appalling phenomenon of illegal organ trafficking as the basis for an almost-as-appalling hyperventilated thriller.
A surprisingly warm variation on an often venal tale, Henry Phillips's pseudo-autobiography affectionately reflects, rather than coldly lampoons, the life of a stand-up.
An awkward, unforgivably slack thriller that takes elaborate pains to show how supposedly easy it is to go from heartbreak to homicide.
Pasta's maximalist approach repels any emotional investment, even as Loureiro and Martínez make for an appealing screen couple among the appalling settings.
Three rising stars of 1989 collectively hit career bottom in director Jonathan Mossek's unintentionally uproarious psychothriller...
The performance sequences feel intimate and exhilarating -- but in the end, Li's journey is compelling only when he's onstage.
I used to think art was just bourgeois decadence, a wiser Craig says in the end, which is funny, because thats kind of what this film is.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a functional sequel, but with all that spirited slicing and dicing, the director could have at least broken a sweat.
It's less a film than one long advertisement for itself -- and for the fact that mindless entertainment truly knows no borders.

The Social Network succeeds, per journalism's most basic directive, in showing not telling. And like great journalism, a great film can capture the reality of the present -- and even make art out of it.

Suffice to say that Blake Nelson doesn't have the visual gifts of his Minnesotan mentors, leaving us undistracted by surface flair and fully focused on his cartoonish characters and ragged, oddly callow script.
Devil packs a lot of business into 80 brisk minutes but is shockingly short on fun or fright.
Stone really does rock Easy A, making Gluck's valentine to Hughes into something lovable in its own right.
The Virginity Hit is elevated by its cast of very funny young actors who match good comic timing with relaxed spontaneity.

Writer, director and star Katie Aselton offers an indecent proposal of a story that initially suggests an honest reconsideration of monogamy -- then quickly, steadily devolves into a moralizing fable.

Even Miyazaki and his Studio Ghibli wizardry can't ward off this story's jinxes.
It's utterly impossible not to pull for these boys, or for a film that sees them as complex individuals rather than sociological evidence.
There's a heart here, but with all the superficial noise, it's hard to hear it beating.
Mythologizing by way of whip-pans and slapstick spit-takes, CBGB just might be the CBGB that we deserve.
It's all very handsomely arranged, but even with the concert footage, nothing ever feels live.
The ace in the hole is Groff, who fluidly slides between lip-curled sarcasm and teary-eyed vulnerability-he's the embodiment of the thrill and terror of being a not-so-little boy lost.

Given only hints of personalities and the thinnest strands of stories, we're left with a hum of tinny snippets instead of anything that resembles the glorious noise of people putting on show after show after show.

As listless and self-regarding as its protagonist, flitting among underdeveloped characters and subplots and indulging in rote emo shots by the pool, yet never figuring out how to dive into the deep end.
It leaves you without the net of linear temporality, frightened and freed by the implications.
Argentine screenwriter turned director Santiago Mitre's drama thrusts us into a maelstrom of intrigue and a bewilderingly fractious debate without fear of losing us along the way.
Evoking a contemporary fable but unfolding like a thriller, You Will Be My Son is most of all a devastatingly realistic depiction of the festering resentments shared between a father and son.

When teenaged Andy plops down on the grass to share his old toys with a shy little girl, the film spikes with sadness and layered pleasure -- a concise, deeply wise expression of the ephemeral that feels real and yet utterly transporting.
[Trueba and Carriere] imbue the material with genuine feeling-exploring the melancholy of waning days and a defiantly naive belief in artistic transcendence.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The extreme variance of style and scrutability makes for wildly disorienting viewing.
It may be the equivalent of NBA stars tossing crumpled paper into a wastebasket, but you're no less compelled to watch old pros go through the motions.
A movie sorely bereft of ideas, laughs and justification for the comic duo's undifferentiating self-regard.
What elevates the film is a pervasive, palpable sense of loss-between lover and beloved, young and old, stage and screen.

An unabashed knockoff of the Taken films ...

movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: The fate of Chinatown Fair makes for a reasonably compelling, if familiar, story... [Yet] it's when the film wanders offsite that its true subject emerges.

A genre-savvy, ethically entangled military thriller by first-timer Michael Connors.

movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)
