Provides several opportunities for Tucker and Chan to do what they do best: Tucker performs comedy sketches, mostly unrelated to the plot, and Chan executes martial-arts fight scenes.
Most of the plotting and situations are trite.
Smith's work is as uneven as ever, but unlike in the past, the director gleefully surrenders any pretense toward making a 'good' or 'serious' film, and the effect is somewhat liberating.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Italian for Beginners may end up a footnote to the Dogma movement history books, but it's a most pleasant little addendum.
More a pair of Jacks than a royal flush.
The cast makes all the angst compelling to watch.
La Cienaga is well worth the trouble finding -- and sitting through -- wherever it plays.
Burns misses a chance to make a witty, observant film about contemporary sexual politics; instead, he comes up with his usual by-the-numbers portrait of lovesick New Yorkers.
It is a minor effort, satisfying only on its own limited terms.
... an upsetting document, but an important one.
In a haze of generic nostalgia, The Majestic hammers home themes of patriotism and family values, all the while rewriting history for its own purposes.
Turns a potentially interesting story into, well, refined sugar.
Yes, one enjoys seeing Joan grow from awkward young woman to strong, determined monarch, but her love for the philandering Philip only diminishes her stature.
This is really just another genre picture.
Wacky and intelligent.
Franklin only takes the worst from Hitchcock (surprise over suspense and a 'lying' flashback red herring), without adding any style of his own.
Gives a whole new meaning to the phrase 'summer camp.'

You've seen it before: the ex-con who stumbles while striving to assimilate back into society. But writer-director Joe Maggio and his able cast makes you care about this man's sorry journey in Virgil Bliss.
Does nothing for gender or culture politics, but it's peppy and colorful, so you might enjoy parts even if you really shouldn't.
For all the film's jauntiness (actually, because of it), it merely depresses.
The film does a solid job of slowly, steadily building up to the climactic burst of violence.
movie_title: Skin of Man, Heart of Beast (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The problem is that Sandler just isn't as fresh or as funny as he used to be.
In his role of observer of the scene, Lawrence sounds whiny and defensive, as if his life-altering experiences made him bitter and less mature.
Lacks originality, inspiration and invention.
Speaks eloquently about the symbiotic relationship between art and life.
If Simone is supposed to offer some kind cautionary message about computers and the media age, it gets lost in Niccol's sloppy screenplay.
A film worthy of comparison to Truffaut's best cinematic poems.
Should be seen by anyone who still romanticizes war, the troops, or the stated motives behind any sort of military conflict.
The film tells its tale so convincingly and stirringly, the familiarity becomes unimportant.
Sometimes obvious, but at other times quite startling.
More a formal treat than a great movie, Almayer's Folly should at least engage fans of director Chantal Akerman.
Pensive, low-key Brazilian thriller is nearly, but not quite, great.
Blinky & Me begs the awkward question: How do you judge an artist whose life is much more compelling than his work?
Do we really need another cannibal movie? A minor mess, Serving Up Richard is almost indigestible.
Switch educates in the manner of a made-for-classroom film... the approach is a little too "balanced" to please anyone on any side of the issue.
Quirky, disarming movie about a woman looking for answers to her troubled life has much to recommend.
"I have become trite, predictable and pretentious," says our writer-hero in The Yakuza and the Mermaid. Sadly, so does the film in which he finds himself.
Gripping documentary about Iraqi orphans should bring attention to a neglected population.
Interesting drama about an Indo-Guyanese teenager suffers from amateurish acting and writing.
Even for those who have seen the kind of productions since inspired by this daring experiment, A Man Vanishes should not be missed-or forgotten.
Heleno might have been stronger by better avoiding the clichés of its genre-yet there are still benefits to this stylish work.
When Woodrow Wilson is a villain in your movie, viewer beware!
Controversial yet meditative French drama makes inscrutability its raison d'etre.
Tedious and slightly sickening, Valérie Massadian's debut feature focuses on a child but is hardly a children's movie.
Insider view of would-be terrorist activity quietly but forcefully packs a punch.
The latest "survival in a confined space" thriller, Detour doesn't take enough of a turn from expected generic conventions.
Documentary about the current state of the meat industry is straightforward yet upbeat, almost "feel-good."
Bidder 70 is modest but revitalizing.
German-language drama features little action but much bittersweet reflection.
What might have impressed on the stage-an attenuated monologue by the heroine-seems forced in the confined space of the dreary one-room bedroom set.
American manufacturing gets glossy, infomercial-style treatment in this tiresome documentary.
Oy! Jewtopia may sound like utopia, but watching it will give you a vision of hell.
Overall, The Network is uneven and unfocused, but not without merit.

The leisurely, intimate [Walter] could have been truly touching but misses the mark. Starting with its misleading title, the film never finds a core message beyond that good, clean living will allow you to live a long time.
movie_title: Walter: Lessons from the World's Oldest People (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Though affecting, Mondays With William should have been more illuminating.
Breezy overview of classic cinematic avant garde will be best appreciated by established fans.
movie_title: Free Radicals: A History of Experimental Film (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another documentary about a supposedly unheralded show-business maverick just barely holds viewer interest.
movie_title: Deconstructing Dad: The Music, Machines and Mystery of Raymond Scott (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The U.S. premiere of this surprisingly thoughtful 1960s spaghetti western gives an opportunity to reflect on the genre.
Insightful look into the world of the mentally disturbed-by a filmmaker who is also his own subject.
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Challenging docudrama about a quixotic crop artist.
This documentary on longevity is more jaunty than illuminating.
Kidnapping thriller isn't quite "so bad, it's good," more like "so bad, it's okay."
Jean-Luc Godard's latest is gorgeously photographed but his most inscrutable film yet.
Informative documentary contains an alarming message.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Challenging, unsettling little movie doesn't quite come together.
Straightforward yet surprising, Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness lives up to its subject's formidable output.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Atmospheric documentary set in Death Valley is surprisingly captivating.
Imperfect but important documentary about subliminal messaging.
Memorable if overemphatic documentary about Bengali laborers.
Likeable leads can't save this dreary sex comedy.
Three friends from a small town in Michigan experience Army life and its after-effects in this plaintive, intimate documentary.
Sadly, what could have been a thoughtful, informative look back turns into a maudlin, overlong "tribute" that will satisfy no one.
Disjointed, wild, but often powerful look at Russian proletariats.
Ambitious but irritating documentary about the Global Village.
movie_title: Connected: An Autoblogography About Love, Death & Technology (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Effective though flawed film works as both revealing documentary and moving family drama.
What the film lacks in originality or wit, it compensates for with solid craftsmanship, a pleasing look and sound, and a great ending.
Mesmerizing, atmospheric concert film reconfigures the genre.
A majestic garden is the real star of this somber yet inspiring documentary.
movie_title: In Heaven Underground: The Weissensee Jewish Cemetery (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It takes excavation on the viewer's part, but Buried Prayers contains people and stories worthy of discovery and discussion.
This documentary about nuclear power plants is as chilling as its title is ironic.
A cross between a feature-length home movie and instant avant-garde classic, El Sicario, Room 164 records a man in a room (though not just any man) talking for 80 charged minutes.
Documentary on the dangers of artificial light alternates between quirky and profound.
The Banality of Evil gets full cinematic treatment in this skillfully made but unpleasant film.
"Tchaikovsky must be grabbed by the throat or it becomes sentimental," declares the paterfamilias in Downtown Express, but the character could be critiquing the very movie in which finds himself.
A fresh, strange, downbeat new entry to the "nonfiction art film" genre.
Earnest attempt to introduce Joseph Campbell's philosophy looks and feels like an infomercial.
Here is a topic worth exploring, but All God's Children doesn't quite reach its destination.

First-time feature filmmaker Anna Condo's Merry Christmas starts with an intriguing idea -- involving a murder-mystery weekend -- but never follows it through with anything especially witty or insightful.
Documentary tackles the divorce industry with the same zeal as the lawyers it rebukes.
Dust may not sound like the most mesmerizing film subject, but Dust makes it so. Hartmut Bitomsky's amazing documentary covers its subject almost as comprehensively as dust covers everything itself.
At once cleverly experimental and mass-appeal action-oriented, but 11 Minutes contains a major flaw that keeps it from being a superior work.
Restored and revived, 1921's 'Destiny' perfectly illustrates the glories of Weimar cinema.
Slow-moving, lengthy yet rarely boring, 'Til Madness Do Us Part reveals the difficult life for the patients inside a psychiatric institution in Southwest China.
movie_title: Feng ai ('Til Madness Do Us Part) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Die-hard wrestling fans might enjoy Lucha Mexico. Everyone else should steer clear.
Co-directors Bingham Bryant and Kyle Molzan show a genuine talent for maintaining a low-grade level of suspense and juxtaposing camera movement and tableaux shots in creative ways.
A muddle of a movie, one which at least preserves some of the Bosch output in a way that even privileged, front-row viewers at the Prado would never be able to enjoy.
movie_title: Hieronymus Bosch, Touched by the Devil (Jheronimus Bosch, Touched By The Devil) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully made portrait of an artist contains a serious and fatal defect.
movie_title: An Art That Nature Makes: The Work of Rosamond Purcell (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Documentary about the "Bushmen" of Namibia gets up close and personal but never connects to its subject.
movie_title: Ghostland: The View of the Ju'Hoansi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating glimpse into the world of a true individualist.
movie_title: Leonard Cohen: Bird on a Wire (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A clever if confusing spoof of the genre pictures [John] Huston had made in a more serious manner in previous years
A riveting oddity.
Outstanding "kino-essay" about one of cinema history's more oddball collaborations-a 1965 formalist experiment by Samuel Beckett and Buster Keaton.
Deceptively simple cinéma-vérité piece is hard to stomach but thought-provoking.
Another 1990s media spectacle gets a long-overdue autopsy in this slick and riveting documentary.
This ostensible farce might be a surprise, but the tragic undercurrent that pervades the storyline fits well into [De Sica]'s longstanding left-wing sociopolitical concerns.
Thanks to an opaque narrative and slow pacing, The Challenge will test your own endurance, but a cult following seems likely.
Frederick Wiseman's 43rd film is as complex and fascinating as his first, released five decades ago.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are more virtues than debits to Time to Die, and Western fans should be relatively satisfied.
Documentary about one of cinema's most infamous scenes gets a razor-sharp, if not entirely thorough, examination.
If you like weirdness for weirdness's sake, you will appreciate all these colorful, unlikely efforts to exhibit East meeting West.

The 19th Annual Animation Show of Shows is a tough call for those seeking consistency. But there are certainly enough enticing shorts within the package to make the weaker portions acceptable to overlook.
movie_title: The 19th Annual Animation Show of Shows (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Homage to Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo and the city of San Francisco is at turns amusing, cryptic, moving and profound.
Lover for a Day offers splendid visuals but little else.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Abbas Kiarostami's final project is a pensive, moody experiment-a challenge to one's patience but an elegiac "last word" (and picture) from a unique and significant filmmaker.
So personal and intimate that it begs only one major question (usually answered by traditional documentaries): Does Cobain really deserve this honor and attention?
Jean-Pierre Melville's quietly affecting film-and Emmanuelle Riva's performance-deserve rediscovery.
movie_title: Léon Morin, Prêtre (Leon Morin, Priest) (The Forgiven Sinner) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Original mixture of techniques makes this documentary provocative yet moving.
Though fragmentary and a bit scattershot, I Don't Belong Anywhere could spark interest in a filmmaker who has been unfairly marginalized in some quarters.
movie_title: I Don't Belong Anywhere - Le cinéma de Chantal Akerman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The U.S. premiere of the newly restored Born in Flames gives us all an opportunity to reassess this indie classic.

With Breaking the Frame, Nitoslawska creates her own work of art -- about a fellow filmmaker -- and makes sure we are all the better for witnessing it. Of course, those who are impatient with experimental cinema may not be appreciative of the effort.
Granted, this is not an exciting or even informative film, and Everson's style is an acquired taste, but The Island of St. Matthews leaves us with sounds and images that resonate.
Though a missed opportunity, Blumenthal contains bits and pieces to savor.
What should have been suspenseful, even terrifying, is tiresome thanks to mostly predictable treatment.
Despite its deficiencies, [the film] at least begins a dialogue about a past that should not be forgotten.
Rumstick Road won't be for everyone, but we are fortunate it exists at all.

Though not dissimilar to other documentaries about artists, Sol LeWitt somehow feels much fresher and more original than those other productions and will hopefully catch on beyond fine-art enthusiasts.
Marc Bauder's quietly disturbing film is near-perfect.

Already a cult film nearly 20 years old, Level Five makes its U.S. theatrical debut, and the wait has turned the viewing experience into something even more meditative than director Chris Marker might have intended.
Yet Nuria Ibanez's blunt little film - her second feature - fails to avoid the pitfall inherent in all such documentaries: the exploitation of its subjects.

Eric Merola does an admirable job of giving a platform to Ralph W. Moss...though the director fails to add many other corroborating voices. Still, Second Opinion's biggest liability might inspire concerned viewers to find out more about the drug
It isn't perfect and could have been much tougher-minded - especially about the country's "selling" of tourism - but this film should start a necessary and overdue conversation.
Deceptively simple film becomes a strange, meditative look into Thai culture and folklore.
Co-directors Paola di Florio and Lisa Leeman honor the man with a reverential though rarely stuffy portrait.
Bittersweet pelican documentary is surprisingly ingratiating.
[Director Howard] Brookner does very little in the way of presenting the material with either wit or imagination.
Hard to Be a God is hard to sit through, though easy to appreciate.
Audiences looking for something offbeat-if also off-putting-should find themselves appropriately bemused.
There is much to like and appreciate in Rebels of a Neon God, even if the tone and subject matter are mostly repellent.
Chagall-Malevich stops short of the kind of inventiveness that would have made the film a true standout of its kind.
Caffeinated never flags completely, but it would not hurt to have a cup of coffee handy while viewing this good-looking but weak concoction.
A Hard Day works best when it doesn't try so hard. Unfortunately, that is not much of the time.
Potentially off-putting, 'The Moving Creatures' blends unlikely genre elements in a surprisingly endearing way.
Seems more like a Lifetime Network movie than something designed for theatrical release.
Stand[s] out from the glut of more recent horror efforts, particularly graphic and gruesome "torture porn"... A haunting and emotionally moving mood piece.
Echoes the style of Luis Buñuel sans the sharp commentary.
movie_title: Bleak Street (La calle de la amargura) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Binoche and most of the cast keep the drama worthy of our attention.
Questionable treatment hurts otherwise important documentary on autism.
Quite frankly, those who care about Lion Ark's mission may as well skip the movie (especially the tedious last section) and contribute to the cause.
Spellbinding little movie deserves lots of attention.
movie_title: I Travel Because I Have to, I Come Back Because I Love You (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Hootnick's approach is far from perfect (formally or politically), but at least it is engaging and worth debating.
The film deserves qualified praise.
City guerrilla filmmaking at its finest.
Despite some very good singing in the opera portions, Wonders Are Many is hard to take seriously.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the dubious moral of the film and on-the-fly camera technique, it is interesting to watch the pathetic story unfold.
Leisurely paced and beautifully lensed, yet reveals hard truths about human frailty in the face of social and familial ills.
It has a relevant and important style and message of its own.
Educational and enlightening.
Pleasing though less-than-profound homage.
Suh reassures us that democracy is alive and well (dispelling the myth of the apathetic young voter), while making us pause to consider the kind of people who emerge from the system.
Secrecy may sound like the latest grade-B horror flick, but it's a horror movie of another kind: a documentary exploring the history of U.S. government clandestiness.
Mattie Fresno and the Holoflux Universe instantly recalls What the Bleep Do We Know? from 2004. But the mixture of jumbled narrative and metaphysical musings simply doesn't work.
movie_title: Mattie Fresno and the Holoflux Universe (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Dear Zachary is a very difficult film to review or rate. This video missive from a man to his murdered friend's son is harrowing and heartfelt but also overemphatic. It seems cruel to criticize a loving, low-budget video production, but the fact is
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like an episode out of Ingmar Bergman's Scenes from a Marriage, Stages distills the essence of a divorce into a few select moments. This Dutch import is hardly groundbreaking, but it captures human beings in existential crisis better than ma
Possibly too restrained for its own good, the fictional story still makes a quiet impact.
Josh Koury's lighthearted documentary may only appeal to the faithful, but, apparently, the faithful comprises an enormous number of people.
An unusual and sobering documentary which turns conventional wisdom about health matters on its head.
Another rewarding dark satire from Romania, the feature debut of a director who died tragically young.
...The Lodger ends up just another modern-day policier, on the order of an extended "Law & Order" episode.
It would take a pretty good filmmaker to turn Grandma's old home movies and audio tapes into something mysterious and chilling, but Morgan Dews has done that with this provocative documentary.

Philosophy as a film subject doesn't usually sell many tickets, but hopefully Examined Life will be the exception. This penetrating documentary covers some of the more original thinking of the last several years through interviews with engaging pro
JFK meets Notes on a Scandal meets Rear Window? An American Affair has some promise and potential, but its main ideas remain messy and undeveloped.
Pleasant, low-key drama about two small-town families with secrets. Though familiar in many respects, Mary Stuart Masterson's feature directorial debut has a quiet charm.
Adding to the glut of slacker-loser comedies, Skills Like This isn't particularly good or bad, just very average.
A solid cast helps this quirky little comedy of existential angst.
Even though this production was completed in 2006, the racial politics of the current presidential election make his film all the more significant.
The American title doesn't do it justice, but Stuff and Dough is a small triumph.
If nothing else, it might change stereotypical perceptions about convicts and prison life.
Nuanced and emotionally bittersweet%u2014not nearly as propagandistic (in either direction) as some might expect.
Unusual film documents time passing by in the lives of an elderly woman and a former political prisoner.
Well-crafted but not very enlightening. The ending will leave you both cold and confused.
What really keeps Lynch interesting is its coverage of the production process; the access is so intimate, we feel as if we are witnessing firsthand the birth of something artistic and significant.
The filmmaker elegantly documents both the past and the present with a measured yet heartfelt sincerity.
It's a must-see for everyone, especially the Lou Dobbses and Tom Tancredos of the world.
You don't have to like or even appreciate Ayler's striking brand of music to be moved by this heartfelt tribute.
For Dylan fans, 65 Revisited will be a treat; for others, it gives a positive glimpse into the world of the folksinging wunderkind.
Though the film may not change many minds about what happened and why, at least it attempts to describe and explain events like few other documentaries on the same topic.
Badland takes a step in the right direction by attempting to understand the aftermath of war.
Feels more like an exploitation B movie for those who get off on rough prison wardens and mistreated, hapless victims.
Even non-jazz fans will enjoy the filmmaker's personal approach to uncovering the mystery surrounding Jackie Paris' career.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Undoing isn't a bad film; it's just not anything great or worth recommending.
Director Sergei Loznitsa says more about Soviet art and politics than any talking head or narrated documentary ever could.
The humor and eccentricity of the band members should prevent a "Who cares?" response, and the twist that occurs in the final section of the piece will keep every viewer mesmerized.
While the celebratory finale is supposed to be uplifting, it could just as easily be described as depressing and disturbing.
The surprise is how consistently entertaining Flakes is despite the dearth of star power, production value or innovative style.
Despite its vivid and imaginative style, The Killing of John Lennon is tough slogging for its nearly two-hour running time.
Falls into the some of the same traps as the films it politely criticizes.
movie_title: Imaginary Witness: Hollywood and the Holocaust (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film misses several opportunities to be more than a fawning portrait.
War Made Easy contributes a significant argument and does a good enough job in a limited way.
How to Rob a Bank? How Not to Make a Movie.
At times, it becomes reminiscent of the well-meaning but racist documentaries of the distant past and suffers from an unintentionally patronizing Nanook of the North syndrome.
Despite some strategic errors, director Newton I. Aduaka uses documentary techniques to inform a challenging and disturbing subject.
As Wiseman's first film in his 40-year career to deal overtly with literal political matters, State Legislature stands apart.
While the murder mystery seems somewhat familiar, at least the style enriches the substance.
Most of the footage is mundane stuff, following Hoffman around farms and factories. I wish the film had been more compelling.
This solid, straightforward film highlights an important part of modern world history, but then overstays its welcome.
Yet another entry about a lonely person discovering him or herself through dance. Though bittersweet and nicely made, Marlene Rhein's feature offers nothing new.

Almost too ready-made for a movie, this documentation of the lives of a troubled artist, his doting wife and his two grown sons should be dramatic and compelling, but comes across like a mockumentary of cinematic self-discovery.
A modern-day, Teutonic Postman Always Rings Twice? Yes, Jerichow is just that, but minus the needed passion or suspense.
Revival of a startling 1956 film reminds us the "good old days" weren't so good for everyone.
Nightmarish tale of existential crisis both disturbs and delights.
movie_title: The Temptation of St. Tony (Püha Tõnu kiusamine) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Appealing documentary about autism is hurt by some aspects of its storytelling.
movie_title: A Mother's Courage: Talking Back To Autism (Sólskinsdrengurinn) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Nazi trial documentary, never before released in the U.S., proves significant and relevant.
A compilation of nine animated short films from around the world contains hits and misses.
Wistful documentary about utopia just misses the mark.
An important political subject gets sincere but slick treatment
Well-crafted domestic melodrama stays lightly likable.
Interesting but unpleasant documentary about the "empty nest" syndrome.
A decent way to get to know a small group of New York-based musicians who have been performing together since the early 1990s.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Coffee-table art book meets musical documentary in this enormously satisfying endeavor.
Small-scale drama gains from its performances and location photography.
Worth seeing by anyone who cares about animals.
Czech family drama neatly blends the personal and the political.
Better in concept than execution, Ward No. 6 is a disappointing modern-day adaptation of a short story by Anton Chekhov.
More mundane than magical, The Strange Case of Angelica is neither strange nor lively enough to lift anyone's spirits.
Highly informative, relatively upbeat take on global warming.
Both humorous and horrifying, this documentary drives home the point that we are dying from our own materiality.
Sad and sobering account of human-rights violations in modern-day China.
Unsettling, evocative tale of an artistic yet dysfunctional family.
...it's difficult to recommend Johnny Mad Dog, despite-and in some ways because of-the fact it is very good.
Cannibal movie is well-cooked but hard to swallow.
Imagine Gummo without the bizarre humor and you have Putty Hill.
A great art-history tale becomes a good but less-than-remarkable film.
Bitter documentary takes the old Soviet Union to TASS.
Sitcom-style feature about a rock duo has too few genuine moments.
A much better movie than its off-putting title would suggest, Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie will introduce many to a singularly altruistic individual.
movie_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful if slightly limited revisit to the "forgotten war," the American involvement in the Korean conflict.
Coming-of-age tale proves to be more arty than interesting.
Excellent documentary corrective to Mississippi Burning-type melodramas.

It is hard to see how "The Big Shot-Caller" will catch fire with audiences. From its awkward, ambiguous title to its lack of charismatic performers, this minor drama doesn't have many commercial prospects.
A good cast of character actors almost save Unbeatable Harold, yet another over-the-top Vegas comedy about lovable losers.
Lee Anne Schmitt's simultaneously haunting and tiresome documentary is like a New Age western with its fond look backward and harsh criticism of the present.
Affecting documentary about grieving mothers on a humanitarian trip to Africa.
Involving doc about the devastating impact of oil exploration on Ecuador's rainforest community.
Despite its age, Araya feels as current as ever.
Biased as journalism but engrossing as a movie, this documentary about a controversial Holocaust figure should be taken with a grain of kosher salt.
Documentary takes a unique and ambitious big-picture approach to a daunting, seemingly endless problem.
Though the year has just started, Leonard Cohen Live at the Isle of Wight 1970 may well turn out to be one of the best films of 2010.
movie_title: Leonard Cohen Live at the Isle of Wight 1970 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A mesmerizing intermingling of life and art, fact and fiction.
Falling Awake isn't completely soporific, but it hardly inspires or enlightens.
Documentary focuses on the despair of one extended family, but might as well represent an uncompromising, microcosmic study of American poverty.
Israel's 2009 Academy Awards Foreign Film entry has been getting good buzz and deserves most of it.
NoBody's Perfect is the completely perfect title for a near-perfect movie about grown "children of Thalidomide."
This mesmerizing little tale is mysterious but straightforward enough to win over any audience.
movie_title: Eccentricities of a Blonde-haired Girl (Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Circus drama from famed helmer is more curio than classic.
movie_title: 36 vues du Pic Saint Loup (Around a Small Mountain) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: American small-town life is the subject of this interesting, stunningly photographed but less than profound documentary.
Filmmakers George and Mike Kuchar get their due--and then some--in this breezy, entertaining overview of the brothers' work.
Slickly produced but devoid of purpose, Convention tackles several storylines occurring at the 2008 Democratic National Convention.
Engaging but ironically lightweight, The Nature of Existence offers differing views about The Meaning of Life.
Johan Grimonprez sure knows his Hitchcock! Double Take is a dazzling and dizzying avant-garde documentary homage--and then some.
Intriguing experimental feature takes playful aim at the North Korean propaganda machine.
Enjoyable and accomplished.
Rare film clips are the highlight of this chronicle of the friendship and falling out of French New Wave icons Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut.
movie_title: Two in the Wave (Deux de la Vague) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A guerrilla-style artist gets a guerrilla-style portrait in this deliberately provocative but unsatisfactory documentary.
movie_title: Dirty Hands: The Art & Crimes of David Choe (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An eager-to-please documentary about teenage science experts, Whiz Kids mostly avoids the dark side of life, though its innocence is somewhat refreshing.
Go in preparation for the upcoming holiday season; don't go expecting groundbreaking CGI...
Suffers from a contemporary take on a very period piece.
Makes its big screen debut with all the pomp and circumstance expected of most sword and sandal epics...
The filmmakers would have been better served letting its predecessor exist undisturbed in the pop culture lexicon...
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What sets this outing apart from the three that have come before it is its darker tone.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Succeeds at bringing an important part of sports -- and American -- history into the minds of today's audiences.
Star power is not enough to save this film from mediocrity.
Sure, Shaun of the Dead may have unlocked the door for movies of this ilk. But Black Sheep kicked it off the hinges and paved the way for a second coming in horror comedies.
The final chapter in the videogame franchise deviates too far from its roots to be saved.
Everything you want in a Hulk film; nothing you don't.
Its darker tone and well turned performances lend credibility and urgency to the story, but the forced Disney/Walden-style kiddie pandering makes for a rather schizophrenic experience.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stronger female leads make this Apatow-produced comedy a well-balanced film.

The hilarious Knocked Up is a great companion piece to 40 Year Old Virgin. Taking the struggles that haunt a mismatched relationship to the next level, Heigl and Rogen light up the screen with the comedic help of a fantastic supporting cast.
Donald Cried is free of "nice guy" characters and never relies on raunchy humor, the exclusions of which give the movie a greater sense of verisimilitude.
Donner, the director, appears to have had next to no control over the proceedings; it looks as though he was enjoying the fun so much that he didn't much bother to direct.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
An incendiary mix of politics, religion, war, violence and personal turbulence -- not an easy film, but a complicated work of art.
Quote not available.
There is less reporting on poverty in America than on any other major societal issue. So it is with AIDS. That alone makes The Normal Heart an important film.

I suspect that von Trier, like many of his European counterparts, views American sexual mores as fairly puritanical. And yet there's something awfully retrograde about a film which offers us a nymphomaniac only to have a man defend her.
It is hard to place one's affections anywhere in a world which is ruled by buttons and dials, computers and bleeps, and people whose conversation is... technical, inaudible or dull.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Ours not to reason why with "Goldfinger"; ours but to gape and admire; which is very easy and enjoyable until the story's iceberg of extravagance finally appears in its true proportions.
We never really feel involved with the story, as all of its ideas remain just that: abstract ideas.
The script is full of witty dialogue and simple yet complex situations.
A wholly original and entirely offbeat, dark comedy about fame, obsessive fandom, and the medium from which they both feed: television.
Certainly worth a peek, if not for the debut work of a director and screenwriter, then at least to see more of Hoffman's great, even if typical, performance.
It has a good soundtrack, lots of free-for-all dance scenes, and derision toward aging singers and capitalists. And you just can't get enough of that.
The movie's ambition of melding spy-thriller drama with gloriously violent action flick falls apart when the former fails to keep pace with the latter.

It wearily welds together nostalgia money lines, the tones of two different movies and some of the most hilarious product placement in cinematic history. Then it throws a dark blue Instagram filter on it and calls it a (very long, disjointed) day.
It's Copley, odious and charismatic, who steals the show, which is obviously the point of casting Sharlto Copley in your hyper-stylized shoot-em-up.
The movie does what it set out to do: entertain its core audience of guys like me who were weaned on Beavis and Butt-head.
Through its powerful emotions coupled with exquisite restraint, this 'small' film makes a big impact.
The psychology feels jarringly anachronistic.
Swarming with ideas, the film never turns schematic or hectoring.
Without the sardonic rant of Philip Roth, upon whose novel the film is based, the material plays as stale or preposterous.
Inarritu and his fellow artists have contrived something wondrous, a formally innovative fugue filled with demons and despair that somehow comes down on the side of life.
Even burdened with flaws demonlover is an original cyber-thriller with a potent message from the ever-surprising and gifted Assayas.
Seldom have grouches, misfits and, yes, nerds seemed so endearing.
Swimming Pool is an entertaining act of provocation that lingers in the mind like iridescent fabric: Turn it one way and it yields this; turn it another and it's a different story.
This full-metal blast at the military is dark, rough-hewn, often hilarious -- and a star-maker for the electric Joaquin Phoenix.
Once you downshift to the film's dreamy rhythms, this multiple prize-winner at Cannes and entry in the 2003 New York Film Festival offers modest rewards.
A magically dislocated world quite unlike any current filmmaker's, one that provokes laughter, sadness and uplift all at once.
Tedious exercise in navel-gazing.
Cholodenko has pulled finely calibrated ensemble work from her perfectly cast actors who, despite varied backgrounds, are on the same page and bring a rare authenticity to their interactions.
The film gradually seduces with its mix of dark humor and pathos, poetic, circus-like music, and haunting characters.
Green's refusal to deliver a clear-cut denouement is less a tease or failure of imagination than a haunting truth about wounding love. He has bored deep into the American core and come up with gold.
You leave the theatre buoyed by the image of two men who put conscience before personal safety.
Amply rewards those willing to embrace its austerity.
For its seriousness, high literary aspirations and stunning acting, the film can only be applauded.
Despite its surface allure and hi-lit cred, the hero remains opaque, the structure is episodic, and the film never quite attains the epic sweep it aspires to.
A film that brilliantly works the intersection of the personal and the political.
Like few filmmakers, Bertolucci captures ... the sexual delirium of youth.
An innovative ride that carries the viewer into a world familiar from genre films and the novels of Dashiell Hammett, yet quite unlike anything we've seen before.
Its novelistic breadth, pitched intensity and on-the-fly shooting style pull the viewer smack-dab into the middle of these lives.
Preachy, schematic and numbingly predictable.
Miraculously manages to be not merely ferociously partisan, but dramatically compelling and a feast for the minds of moviegoers, not overly nourished these days.
In a triumph of filmmaking, Arnold has endowed a tale of female rage with disquieting social resonance.
A soaring, tragic tale of transcendence and forgiveness that resonates long after the credits roll.
Will prove more compelling as a technical study for Film Studies majors than as an entertainment for a general audience.
This Gallic tourist-porn feels as stale as yesterday's baguette.
Clooney confidently lasers away the characters' personal lives to focus on Murrow's maneuverings.
Worth watching for its good-humored energy, exposure of social ills, and acting by impeccable pros along with a fabulous newcomer.
Succeeds as an exercise for the excellent Nichols, even when its theatrical origins fight with the medium of film.
It's Depp, sporting a Scottish accent, who carries the film with his daringly underplayed portrait of a man more at home in idyllic forests and lagoons than his own drawing room.
Offers up a brave, spot-on portrait of one man pulverized by the system during the Watergate era.
This is a middling venture destined for English lit courses.
Rises above its own shortcomings through Heath Ledger's electric embodiment of Ned.
This foreign import is more than just a suspenseful wartime story; there's a lack of cynicism, a willingness to embrace human possibility that's as old-fashioned as it is refreshing.
Should be made mandatory viewing in places low and high.
Cuts it as thinking man's sci-fi, and marks another stretch for the ever-fertile Winterbottom.
Offers a startling mix of genres: a memory piece drenched in nostalgia for a lost childhood, clothed in the form of a thriller that grabs you by the throat.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The film's take on filial love is fresh and affecting. Its political savvy yields sharp insights.
It's riveting and on-message, and showcases a new facet of a brilliant actor's burgeoning career.
The characters are more deeply thought through than in most 'right-thinking' films.
So murkily executed that the ending is all but indecipherable through the pea-soup.
In its chicken heart, Crush goes to absurd lengths to duck the very issues it raises.
A wildly funny prison caper.
[Fessenden] weaves a creepy spell by crafting a kaleidoscope of puppetry, sounds and cinema legerdemain.
Even these old pros ... fail to lift a leaden balloon of a movie.
Montiel's first effort remains episodic and inward, failing to build a bridge to the viewer.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Delivers a rewarding story about the return to one's roots and the human potential for renewal.
The film's episodic structure finally proves maddening.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The genuine feel-good article.
Thirteen Conversations About One Thing lays out a narrative puzzle that interweaves individual stories, and, like a Mobius strip, elliptically loops back to where it began.
Gooses a creaky genre into new relevance, but it offers no compelling stories and largely wastes the talents of its stellar cast.
Though fancifully constructed, Happenstance is principally the visualization of a concept, and in the end, more of a moving board game than a movie.
It's dispiriting to see the French relinquish all irony and attempt to out-schlock the Americans.
Demands too much of most viewers.
movie_title: Ni na bian ji dian (What Time Is It Over There?) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Throughout this aerial confection, 'real life' and artifice are intriguingly intertwined.
Lacking any center, in its pandering heart the movie tries to be something for everyone.
Though Tran places special demands on his viewers, those prepared to enter his magical world will hunger to return.
movie_title: The Vertical Ray of the Sun (Mua he chieu thang dung) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining and provocative tale of ordinary people who suddenly find themselves heroes.
A low-budget, deceptively minimalist drama that delivers big.
While Breillat's latest does not exactly qualify as entertainment, it makes the unwatchable something we want dearly to watch.
The film raises predictability to new levels.
A spunky, original take on a theme that will resonate with singles of many ages.
Though certainly original in form, Altar Boys requires a taste for Swamp Thing-type animation, doubled with a deafening score.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Miller comes at film with bracing intelligence and a vision both painterly and literary.
More whiny downer than corruscating commentary.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Open-ended and composed of layer upon layer, Talk to Her is a cinephile's feast, an invitation to countless interpretations.
A sustained fest of self-congratulation between actor and director that leaves scant place for the viewer.
A marvel of production design.
Why did such fine actors sign on to this lollapalooza?
Its keenly observed set-pieces never add up to a larger picture.
A guilty pleasure, like chocolate truffles.
Let's salute Rohmer's ability at 81 to bend the latest technology to his unique cinematic vision.
Bravely explores the psychic damage inflicted on Jean-Luc by a withholding, then absent parent.
movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Chabrol brilliantly conjures menace from the everyday and familiar.
Though not much seen on these shores, Italian cinema, to judge by The Last Kiss, is alive and well.
Part of the film's cheeky charm comes from its vintage schmaltz.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Consistently entertaining, with witty dialogue and a kind of Gallic concision, shaved of superfluous moments.
While you could never fault Sayles for speedy exposition, the donkey-cart pace makes you want to whip the thing along.

With a small budget and a brilliant team, director/co-writer Jonathan Parker has brought new relevance to Bartleby's revolt, and converted an office sitcom format into a damning critique of the way many people spend their days.
Anderson brilliantly conjures a goofy, skewed world as seen by a hyper kid.
Tweaking genre convention at every turn, Taylor has created a shimmering entertainment that leaves you, well, humming 'Cherish.'
Apparently writer-director Attal thought he need only cast himself and his movie-star wife sitting around in their drawers to justify a film.
For all its Sundance cool factor, the latest from this gifted director glances off the viewer without leaving much impact.
Chouraqui earnestly displays the Balkan horrors till we scarcely react any more to the latest deafening detonation or pile-up of bodies.
This powerful film celebrates individual acts of conscience in barbarous times.
Madding Crowd will remind viewers of how hungry they are for an epic romance minus the cynicism and snark.
Sharply observed, often LOL comedy about artistic integrity and the shrinking horizons of middle age.
Exercising spectacular control, director David Cronenberg permits not a single iota of humanity or altruism to sneak into this twisted tale.
A nuanced, humanistic portrait of a town besieged by jihadists, its images of violence suffused with almost surreal dreaminess.
In the marvelous, immersive A Most Violent Year, [J.C.] Chandor broadens his canvas, proving himself a major filmmaking talent.
Foxcatcher weaves its spell through the cunning use of unhurried silences...-rarely does a director display such control of his materials.

But Stevens and Katz give naturalism a bad name by making it boring. Land Ho! intends to affirm that even for the graying population, life offers surprises, renewals, fun. Sadly, they're only experienced by the gents onscreen.

In its focus both on the looming disaster of climate change and the swelling economic disparity between the rich and everyone else, it's both timely and relevant, while keeping the entertainment quotient high.
A lovely addition to Ken Loach's cinema of working-class heroes, this true story of Irish agitator James Gralton is intelligent, gorgeously shot, and makes the heart sing.
This pungent comedy set in combat's erogenous zone is Polanski at the top of his game.
The Double draws on past literary giants to nail a current malaise with offbeat humor and visionary flair.
This brilliant dissection of family dynamics and the tyranny of the past weds honesty with slow-burn drama and peerless acting.
Despite the offbeat-pun intended-casting, in Kill Your Darlings the richly gifted Krokidas delivers a terrific entertainment which updates this origin story with its stinging critique of homophobia.
And though the plot is wafer-thin, 'Bodies' is less about story than mood and visual poetry, playing like a folk ballad about criminal lovers.
A way-cool account of a real-life crime spree in Southern California that trips on Sofia Coppola's failure to take a directorial stance.

This third chapter hits new highs as Richard Linklater gets down and dirty about the challenges of long-term commitment. The ongoing saga of Jesse and Celine makes for one of the most engaging love stories in contemporary cinema.
A genre-twisting documentary with a fictional vibe that playfully bares the elusive truths about a family of storytellers.
Departing her trademark dramas, noted Danish filmmaker Susanne Bier remixes the rom-com in a sparkling cocktail that celebrates the messiness of life.

Filth, another wild ride drawn from Irvine's fiction, will likely appeal only to diehard proponents of the writer's dystopian vision. Complicating the issue, though, is the performance of James McAvoy, which is nothing short of extraordinary
The period detail is perfect and the lensing nails the novel's frenzied rhythms, but a literal-minded approach and miscast lead stall this baby before the finish line.
Lacks narrative heft and momentum.
An old-school, emotionally soaring take on an Irishwoman's new life in America, interrupted by the lure of the old sod, featuring a star-making turn by Saoirse Ronan.
The auteur's unbeatable weirdness here mutates into preciosity.
Trafficks in exploitative images of women in the guise of art-film license.
[A] blistering and timely account of the privileged classes, relayed with dark humor and impeccable craft.
Mingles realism and the surreal to convey the immorality of war.
Oh hell, it's refreshing to see a woman give a man a taste of his own Don Juan.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: This Palme d'Or winner is a meaty film of ideas with instant-classic set-pieces and moments of mind-blowing freakiness, a stunning follow-up to Force Majeure.
Coasts mainly on surfaces. Issues and questions are raised, grazed, but remain unexplored.
Brad Pitt nails it as a four-star general out to win an unwinnable war in this savage, often hilarious but tonally uneven satire skewed at thinking adults.
A screwball comedy from a master filmmaker reaches moments of inspired pandemonium, but a plot centered on lecherous men quickly palls.
A well-crafted bagatelle about the self-renewal of a neglected wife that hits all the Screenwriting 101 points.
A scalding, perfectly wrought film about a man's struggle to assert his dignity in a bureaucratic system that's rigged to destroy it.
A moving if somewhat elusive meditation on human aloneness and independent women at odds with their environment.
A misfire from distinguished stage director Michael Grandage about the artistic and emotional interplay between Thomas Wolfe and fabled Scribner's editor Maxwell Perkins.
A delicious marriage of Whit Stillman and Jane Austen in a comedy of manners with a contemporary spin that delights from start to twisty finish.
Ralph Fiennes steals the show in a riveting erotic thriller from the director of I Am Love about a foursome up to no good on a Mediterranean getaway.
Golden Days [...] feels too insular, as if created for [director Desplechin] and a circle of intimates, rather than the rest of us sitting out there in the dark.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A stunning cinematic achievement thanks to gifted director Andrew Haigh, who pulls indelible turns from Brit screen legends Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.
At once visually stunning and a candidate for the season's most irritating and pretentious work.
An elegant anthem to one man's effort to make sense of a tortuous past and achieve closure, anchored by mesmerizing turns from Jim Broadbent and Charlotte Rampling.
In this classy, immersive drama, a renowned string quartet must recalibrate following the illness of its patriarch.
Timothy Spall etches an indelible portrait of the great painter, aided by a marvelous supporting cast who make the period spring alive.
A heat wave draws a group of New Yorkers into a ring of seduction and desire in this shoddy exercise marked by posturing and pretention.
A bold, riveting tale of wartime resistance borrowing the form of a noir thriller.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A bold, riveting tale of wartime resistance borrowing the form of a noir thriller.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In this brilliant and provocative chamber piece, the ever-inventive Steven Soderbergh captures the life of a high-end call girl, equating it with the entrepreneurs she services.
Gregor Jordan and Bret Easton Ellis take no prisoners in this uncompromising, expertly crafted shocker about hedonism in early-'80s L.A.
This reunion of old college friends gets a leaden treatment in what is effectively a one-act play posing as a film.
Tom Tykwer's globe-spanning thriller about corporate malfeasance offers ideas, pace, beauty, and an aces turn from thinking-man's action hero Clive Owen.

Recreating true events, this rousing, impeccably lensed World War II drama depicts Jewish partisans battling Nazis in the woods of Belarus, with Daniel Craig and Liev Schreiber outdoing themselves as heroic fighters.
For those willing to enter its dangerous world, the rewards of this film are great.
This collage of vignettes breathes life into New York's edgy lovers.
At film's end, we happily say adieu to a pair who deserve each other more than they imagine.
[Moore] turns potentially dry material into a film that's funny, poignant, and a call to arms.
Those willing to stay with this often demanding film, though, will find an unusually balanced view that celebrates not only Mariane's courage, but the Pakistanis who fought valiantly on her behalf.
Southern pulp trash centered on a miscarriage of justice during the Civil Rights era that's wildly entertaining due to fearless turns from Nicole Kidman, John Cusack and a half-naked Zac Efron.
Pacey and entertaining, it's anchored by a zesty turn from Richard Gere, and it deftly evokes, through music and news clips, the early '70s of Nixon and anti-war protests.
This film leaves you hoping for a project truly worthy of Gordon-Levitt's gifts.
The film generates such visceral heat, the whole notion of genre becomes irrelevant.
The film will likely divide viewers, striking many as a self-indulgent wallow, others as a rewarding envelope-pusher. In fact, it combines elements of both.
Viewers here can't help but respond to the raw emotions and acting ability of the largely nonprofessional cast.
Even the lineup of superlative thesps can't mask the pandering, manipulative ploys at the film's cheesy heart.
This original but overlong fable about a family menaced by industrial progress captures fears about a planet out of control.
David Duchovny as the writer delivers a turn so listless and bland, you want to goose him with a cattle prod.
Unscrolling at the intersection of high art, drama and sex, Coco Chanel & Igor Stravinsky brings a pair of legends to vibrant life.
This psychological thriller from Argentine Juan José Campanella boasts a fine cast and spiky dialogue, but thematic bloat blunts its power.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A rich, multi-strand excursion into fatherhood, creativity and desire anchored by a dream cast and set amidst offbeat Venice locales.
A riveting, deftly crafted sci-fi thriller that plays mind games with the viewer.
A reunion of four college friends sheds little light on the male psyche in this garbled and unwatchable film
This riveting, knockout punch of a film about a sex addict works the intersection of art, tone poem and social critique.
This shivery account of the fallout from a creepy cult on a young woman deftly combines the horror-thriller genre with naturalistic drama and marks the arrival of a gifted young director.
This indie gem explores with uncommon insight the eroding effects of long distance on love.
A dour Nordic humor informs this small but appealing comedy of couples in crisis in the snowy North.
In a remarkably assured debut, Mike Cahill and Brit Marling, his star and co-writer, churn a mesmerizing tale of redemption through a sci-fi premise about a twin planet.
A seductive if uneven attempt to bring to the screen a cult novelist's vision of young love.
Gifted newcomer Richard Ayoade delivers a delightfully edgy romp about first love, styled as a home movie and diary, and starring Craig Roberts in a career-making turn.
Lovers of Charlotte Bronte's classic will luxuriate in the spooky Gothic atmosphere, but the film's pallid Jane fails to nail a character who changed how women view themselves.
...it's refreshing to encounter a deeply involving film unafraid of raw, visceral emotion, a film that for once thinks almost too big.

From venerable French filmmaker Alain Resnais comes a trippy, genre-bending meditation on the vagaries of passion that widens the boundaries of cinema, but engages the intellect more than the emotions.
Powerful, raw and fluidly shot, this history of a marriage told in shuffled time stars Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling, two of our finest young actors.
A blistering, eye-opening documentary with the potential to change America.

With newspapers going bankrupt country-wide, director Andrew Rossi offers an up-close view of the players, stories and struggles at America's paper of record, making a persuasive case for traditional newsgathering
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Soaring visuals of the mighty mount combine with a portrait of intriguing George Mallory to hit a new peak in adventure filmmaking.
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In this lumbering farce with maudlin top notes, a group of displaced Russian musicians attempt to reclaim their former glory.
With its brilliant cinematography by Ennio Guarnieri and cast of pretty faces, the film is like a painting come to life.
movie_title: Brother Sun, Sister Moon (Fratello sole, sorella luna) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Jake told us kids that what we always suspected was true: the summer of love was dead, long live the summer of the shark.
For Bava as for Daibolik, aesthetic beauty and tactile sensation trump emotional connection and spiritual depth.
An intelligent look at a time when the old guard of tough-talking gumshoes and snappy reporters were about to surrender to a new breed: educated and self-aware men and women.
If you're a parent ... this isn't a bad 75-minute distraction for the little ones.
The layered script is alternately hilarious and realistic, horrifying and stilted.
This mushy tale of twenty-something angst is like a Euro version of Reality Bites.
Malkovich squeezes the most from his exotic locations, and the intriguing performances give a human face to its topical subject.
Like a creaky roller coaster, you feel it could fall apart at any time.
Spoiled 20-somethings waxing nostalgic over failed relationships rarely makes compelling viewing for anyone over the legal drinking age, and XX/XY is no exception.
Provokes thought and provides joy in equal measure.
At his best, Griffin recalls a young Richard Pryor.
It's Farrell's portrayal of the smug publicist that turns the improbably absurd premise into weird, pulpy fun.
Victor and Judy are so appealing and realistic in their lead roles that you'll swear you're watching a documentary.
[Rock's] off-the-wall sense of humor and genuinely likable persona overcome his lack of finesse behind the camera.
The film never delivers on its morbid promise, thanks to the character's too-obscure motives and dialogue that's dull when it should be snappy.
Much of the digitally altered footage appears jagged, as if filmed directly from a television monitor, while the extensive use of stock footage quickly becomes a tiresome cliché.
You want explosions, expertly choreographed violence and implausible situations easily remedied by running up a wall and doing a back flip? Cradle delivers the goods.
A pleasant enough romp, but it succumbs to a one-note script that restricts the film's characters from taking advantage of much of its potential hilarity.

The source and the subject matter make it difficult to assign critical judgement to Blind Spot, but the film's snail pace means it will probably appeal mostly to scholars and students of the Holocaust.
Your enjoyment of National Security will be in direct proportion to how much you can tolerate Martin Lawrence's antics.
In the end, viewers will find sympathy for even a low-life like Brogan -- one of the film's many ambiguities that will linger long after the projection bulb has dimmed.
Combining elements of 1984, Fahrenheit 451 and The Matrix, this ridiculous sci-fi mish-mash sounds appealing, but is nothing more than a poorly designed knockoff.
Parallels to Stanley Kubrick's 2001 abound, and Clooney's portrayal of a man offered the opportunity to escape into a world of dreams might be the actor's best work to date.
Robert Harmon's less-is-more approach delivers real bump-in -the-night chills -- his greatest triumph is keeping the creepy crawlies hidden in the film's thick shadows.
The riveting performances by the incredibly flexible cast make Love a joy to behold.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers from a flat script and a low budget.
It's just plain boring.
The film's premise -- that the savvy student played by Charlotte Ayanna would get involved with this creep -- is a stretch at best.
A film about people who feel too much for people who don't think too much.
We've seen it all before.
The so-inept- it's-surreal dubbing (featuring the voices of Glenn Close, Regis Philbin and Breckin Meyer) brings back memories of cheesy old Godzilla flicks.
A perfect date movie for jaded Francophiles.
A compelling slice-of-life narrative that draws much of its strength from its non-professional actors.
Remains compelling even at over two-and-a-half hours thanks to great performances from Law, Zellweger and the collection of cameo appearances from the likes of Giovanni Ribisi and Hoffman.
Serviceable performances from the principals underscore the film's functionality, giving modern star power to its paint-by-numbers plot.

This breezy remake of the 1987 film Can't Buy Me Love is so lightweight it threatens to float off the screen, but likable performances from leads Cannon and Milian go far in helping anchor some of writer/director Troy Beyer's flimsy script.
With a surprisingly resonant emotional undercurrent, this adult relationship comedy comes off as extremely likable, if not lovable.
Dwells in its own abysmal dreariness without creating real suspense, relying instead on a stream of easy shocks to convince us that we're watching a scary movie.
A strangely grim affair that will stretch the patience of more than a few viewers.
Not aspiring to be much more than a simple fish-out-of-water comedy, Elf is sweet and a little hokey -- and has the makings of a holiday classic.
Busch is actually pretty great as Arden, but with nothing to hang his wig on, it all gets tiresome rather quickly, inviting unflattering comparisons to John Waters' superior 1980 effort, Polyester.
Ultimately pointless, this lethargic picture seems to be trying to make a statement but succumbs to its own artiness -- including a cast made up mostly of non-actors.
This sappy, overlong, three-hankie melodrama featuring Gooding Jr. in full-on Rain Man mode is about as corny as they come.
Ignore the Irish fiddle and tin-whistle score and settle in for a compelling and intense story.
A touching tribute to a community celebrating life in the face of tragedy and death.
The filmmakers should've left this story on the bookshelf.
The location camerawork and story are outstanding, but amateurish acting and editing keep this dreamy mess from feeling like a proper movie.
Surprisingly low on laughs considering the talent involved.
Writer-director Jed Weintrob is so busy trying to make important statements about human relationships in the cyber age that he loses control of his whiny, unlikable characters.
This coming-of-age drama, based on the Dodie Smith novel, has the feel of a proper BBC production, but it lacks the energy to compel on the big screen.
The likeable characters and silly situations create a few genuine laughs and the liberal sexual content (by American standards) is surprisingly refreshing.
Unfortunately, a logjam of characters (nearly all from the book are included) means that few get the attention they deserve.
A bit long and pretentious at times, Carnage is still an interesting narrative experiment that recalls some of the more avant garde Eastern European cinema from the early '70s.
Gator's gradual transition from smirking punk to neon-clad cheeseball is vividly told by his former friends and contemporaries.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Filmgoers may debate its allegory and sexual politics, but 28 Days Later is the real deal: a scary flick for uncertain times.
Winterbottom ... proves he's one of the most talented, dexterous filmmakers around with this powerful drama.
Nielsen, Chloe Sevigny and Gina Gershon shine, but ultimately this stylish yet dated arthouse feature is more confused than we are.
Uneven yet often hilarious.

Satoshi Kon and Sadayuki Murai have dispensed with many of the conventions that plague Japanese anime to create an original and compelling animated fantasy that satisfies as both a historical romance and a philosophical drama.
A film with a powerful visual discourse, great atmosphere and in pro of sexual liberation. [Full review in Spanish]
The very low level of comedy (sound effects that follow the movements of the actors like in the worst TV comedy of the seventies) does not permit deepening in its topics. [Full review in Spanish]
A fun and efficient movie full of brilliant and exiting moments, with a a crazy and sometimes cryptic sense of humor. [Full review in Spanish]
Ricciarelli's film denounces wars as a horrible setting for human evil to grow and prey on the poor. [Full review in Spanish]
A journey that's too tiring visually, too rushed narratively speaking and efective just to deliver entertainment. [Full review in Spanish]
A well executed work life thriller with a dash of culture shock comedy. [Full review in Spanish]
A dark comedy that even if you feel like you shouldn't laugh asks the question: Why shouldn't you be allowed to laugh at this stuff? [Full review in Spanish]
